Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, honourable colleagues, our primary objective is to ensure that Europe has a common agricultural policy even after 2013.

We believe this is fundamental not only to protect the agricultural sector and the socio-economic fabric in member states, but also because, at the dawn of the third millennium, it is strategically necessary to ensure food supply security for Europe.

We must maintain partial tied aid until 2013, in order to avoid the complete abandonment of production, because this would jeopardize entire supply chains, creating unemployment as well as various economic and environmental problems in particularly disadvantaged areas.

ITO, which guarantees the opening of markets and a genuine progression towards a system that truly allows the European Union to speak with one voice on energy matters.

We once gathered in this chamber to defend a food, cultural, and rural heritage originating from a tradition centuries old, an invaluable asset that the world envies, representing a substantial wealth for our economy and also for the identity of our Union.

A heritage that today risks facing serious difficulties due to the Commission’s and the Council’s desire to abolish the blending prohibition for the production of rosé wines, a desire born under considerable pressure.

and that it will find its ratification without the possibility of parliamentary intervention, the body that officially represents the millions of citizens—producers and consumers—who will be affected by this initiative.

The Commission proposes allowing red wines to be produced simply by blending red and white wines, as is done in countries that do not possess our expertise and professionalism, using the simple pretext of responding to international competition.
As the confirmer of the questioning, I emphasize that lowering the quality of our productions, the result of centuries of traditions and research, of very significant investments, of passion,
Attention to detail is not the answer we need, especially in a time of economic crisis like this, when the average consumer is certainly paying more attention to price than to writing on a label.

To counterbalance this decision, it would suffice to find a name for the new product and inform consumers of the existence of two distinct types of rosé, the differing quality of the products, and the importance of recognizing the work and efforts of professionals in the sector.
Who will pay for all of this?

Does the Commission envisage any support programs in this regard, or will producers once again be required to foot the bill, after having been asked to fight unfair competition from low-cost providers in already extremely challenging times?
I hope that the Commission and the Council will be able to make the right choice and, if necessary, to revise this procedure entirely.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, allow me first to greet the president of the DTP party, Mr. Ahmet Türk, who is here with us in the gallery of honor and is following the debate.

Dear Ahmet, please know that we stand in solidarity with you, that we support the democratic struggle your party is conducting in Turkey for the recognition of the fundamental rights of the Kurdish people.
We recognize in DTP an indispensable tool for the promotion of democracy in Turkey and, for this reason, we firmly condemn the police operations that the Turkish government is implementing.
Prime Minister Erdoğan ordered against you, incarcerating all three vice presidents of the DTP, together with over 300 militants and supporters.
The victory of the DTP in the latest local elections demonstrates that the DTP party is a party with strong democratic popular support.

The European Parliament, in its resolutions, has called on Prime Minister Erdoğan to initiate direct discussions with the DTP; instead, his response has been further repression, more police presence, greater authoritarianism, and increased incarceration.

Everyone knows that my parliamentary group and the Left in Europe have thus far supported the accession process of Turkey to the European Union, while simultaneously advocating for the reform process in that country.

However, I believe that in these last two years and especially in recent months, Erdoğan has shown another face, that of a leader compromised with the worst elements of the Turkish military, who simply wants to massacre the Kurds.
The reform process is practically dead; prisons are filling with Kurds. It is Erdoğan himself who is closing any perspective of Turkey’s accession.
It is solely his responsibility for what is happening in the Euro-Turkish relations and for the growing perplexity of European public opinion towards Turkey.

I want to send a very strong political message to Erdoğan: either make the pursuit of a negotiated political solution to the Kurdish question a priority – a priority that, let it be clear, passes through direct negotiations with the DTP – or will we be the ones to request the suspension of Turkey’s accession negotiations with the European Union?

The road to Turkey’s accession to the Union passes through Diyarbakir and the DTP; otherwise, we—those who have thus far supported the accession process—will be the ones to call for a period of reflection that risks becoming definitive.

I have already discussed the Turin trial, in which Swiss and Belgian employers are defendants.
Everyone knew little; it was action that was lacking, and industry above all else avoided its responsibilities, acting within the confines of inertia and public authorities.
Examples of inertia are evident, for instance, in Italy, at Brioni, where asbestos has not been removed, at Porto Marghera, and in Cengio, where fatalities continue to be recorded.
Today, industry is calling on the Commission to tolerate yet another exemption already granted for a limited period by the REACH regulation in 2006 regarding chrysotile asbestos fiber.

It is true that low-voltage electrolysis plants have a limited application and are found in only a few installations, but where industrialists claim the impossibility of any alternative substitute, under penalty of plant closure.

A blackmail but alternative approaches to this process have been found in Sweden, utilizing technologies in the replacement of membranes without biasing for low voltage, and an analogous approach has also been adopted for hydrogen production.
Why in some states and not in others?
For, as in the long battle to ban PCBs, there have been countless omissions and reticences, even those supported by the DG Enterprise of the European Commission.
Even in this instance, a good example was not given.

The 1999 directive on the prohibition of asbestos stipulated that the review of such authorization had to be preceded by an opinion from the Scientific Committee on Toxicology, an opinion that was never produced.
Is this how the Commission respects directives?
Not to mention the trade union, which claims it wasn't even consulted.
The European Parliament undertakes its efforts to fulfill the requirements of others.

This resolution requests the Commission to fill a legislative gap by 2009 regarding the prohibition of second-hand products containing asbestos, roofing materials, aircraft parts, and other items that should be disposed of definitively.
If they set precise dates, once again, for a strategy of banning all types of asbestos by 2015, those were targets already written in 1999.
Ten years have passed, and people have continued to die.
The GUE had claimed, among the first initiatives of this legislative term, the establishment of a community fund to compensate victims, and dedicated funds for decontamination.
The request was specific to the Commission, which today instead aligns itself with the will of multinational corporations.
Instead, it is necessary to move to concrete facts and commitments.
Only when these are based on the same requests as this resolution will we be able to be understanding.
Today this will is not evident; therefore, we vote against granting the exemption.
Mr. President, I wished to convey to President Buzek the pride that fills me at this moment in belonging to an important institution such as the European Parliament presided over by you.

I believe that the sacrifices made over the last twenty years in her country and that today are being made by those twelve countries of which we spoke earlier in this Assembly lend strength to Europe.
However, I also want to convey my concern, having listened to her program within her address, that it should—and I hope that it will—give strength to this Parliament.
I hope that what has been announced to us will come to fruition.

I hope that the next president of the European Commission, certainly President Barroso, will want to hear from her regarding the strong words she has spoken to ensure that this Parliament provides answers to more than

The 550 million citizens who voted for us in this Europe, who want us and want and demand from this Parliament, from all of us, the answers that Europe has certainly attempted to give, but has not entirely succeeded in delivering.
Regarding this endeavor of yours, I express my hopes and set them in motion, and I am certain that with you we will achieve the certainties you yourself have welcomed within us.

Mr. President, Commissioner, honorable colleagues, it is neither my intention, nor that of my group, which has supported and desired this debate, to transfer to the European level responsibilities for Italian domestic policy.

The issue of freedom of information concerns us all; it concerns the European Union, which can and must regulate the matter at the community level, in order to counteract political and economic influences and to guarantee genuine pluralism in information.

The Italian anomaly, where the prime minister is also the owner of some of the most important private networks, consists precisely in the existence of a dangerous entanglement between media, political, and economic powers.

It is precisely for this reason that we are calling for European regulatory intervention, an intervention that, far from being an act of anti-Italian sentiment, would serve to protect the pluralism of information, avoiding concentrations and conflicts of interest.

For this reason, today we ask the Commission to intervene as soon as possible, as this Parliament has also requested in the past, to equip the European Union with common rules to protect freedom of information for all European citizens.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I am aware that on September 30th last, the Commission presented a study on indices of media pluralism in the Member States.
But in 2008, a report was voted on, with Marianne Micko as rapporteur, which invited the European Commission and Member States to safeguard, and I quote verbatim, the multiplicity of resources.
of opinions on the media, to defend the pluralism of information, to guarantee all citizens of the European Union equal access to free and diverse information sources.

Earlier still, in 2004, a report was voted on in Parliament, drafted by Bogert Kvack, concerning the risks of violation within the European Union of freedom of expression and information, which requested the Commission to present a communication on ensuring media pluralism in all Member States.
To date, the Commission has not yet provided clear answers to the Parliament's requests.

Note, Madam Commissioner, that I have not named my country nor my Prime Minister, but in this forum, as a European citizen, I ask you what the Commission intends to do at the European level to ensure that media pluralism is guaranteed in all Member States.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the discussion concerning yesterday's vote in the environmental committee has been reported many times.
I would prefer it to be evident, however, that it cannot all be reduced to a single extremist and ideological position.

We have heard many positions from colleagues that have been very varied, very articulated, very practical, and therefore, being more closely aligned with reality, I believe them more capable of providing real answers.
Science as a totem does not exist; when this error was made of identifying a problem in such an ideological manner, answers were not provided, but rather
disasters, and Europe should be a teacher in this regard, not repeating the same errors, even if in different guises and with labels that appear superficially much more amicable.
I must recall that the same emissions trading directive stipulates that the virtuous path of the European Union is to be assessed by the Commission based on the outcomes of the conference.
We at the conference must go, certainly holding strong positions, having clear ideas, but absolutely seeking to equitably distribute interests.

We must also support the efforts of all industrialized countries, first and foremost, which must adopt equivalent emissions reduction targets, but also without forgetting what the colleague Grossetête so clearly recalled, which is now the theme of our discussion.

But among developing countries, we cannot avoid making distinctions; there are developing countries, truly, and there are countries whose economies have now emerged—I am speaking of India, China, and Brazil.
These are countries that cannot but undertake their own commitments.

Instead, I strongly request that, should an agreement not be reached in Copenhagen, the European Union continues to guarantee the allocation of free allowances to at-risk sectors, as stipulated by Directive 2003/CE.

These are fundamental points; we want the Kyoto Protocol itself to maintain its environmental significance and, above all, we want to prevent the creation of a financial bubble at the expense of our European businesses.

It is very important for two reasons: the first is the theme of the research, which concerns the fight against neurodegenerative diseases, and the second is the modality of joint programming in research.
We would, of course, have preferred – and it has been stated and the subject of our inquiry – a more direct involvement of Parliament in the pilot project.

If we are not to halt proceedings and must proceed now, we request assurances that our opinion will be taken into consideration in the Council’s competitiveness deliberations and that a more certain legal basis be clarified for the future, for the full involvement of Parliament and for a more comprehensive entitlement within this area of research.

Now we must intervene with appropriate means and resources to prevent and eradicate a scourge as widespread as Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, and the other diseases destined to increase in the face of an aging population.
We request that attention be focused on large-scale and comprehensive studies, directed both toward diagnosis and the identification of treatments.

Fundamental appear to be the investigations into biomarkers, early diagnosis methods based on a multidisciplinary approach, the establishment of extensive databases, the search for curative medications and models of care and appropriate services.

I feel compelled to offer but one recommendation in this context: do not overlook either the subjectivity of patients, too often excluded in this type of illness, nor the involvement of patient and family associations.
Methodologically speaking, we believe that collaborative research projects are very important because they address a fundamental need: to concentrate efforts and resources.
to overcome those fragmentations, those duplications, and to achieve a critical mass sufficient to yield adequate results for this type of research.

When one considers that in other areas of the world, joint public and private efforts result in investments of tens of millions of euros, we realize how much remains to be done and how much we must do, converging on projects.

on strategic guidelines and shared programs between States and Europe, and on common programs between public and private entities, without neglecting that international framework that connects us with major scientific realities at an international level.
What are the novelties of the Stockholm Programme compared to those of the AIA, a fair balance between rights and security, and legal protection in both criminal and civil fields?
Safety is a right: not to be attacked in the workplace, to walk the streets without risking one’s life, not to be subjected to violence as women, not to be exposed to acts of terrorism.
States and Europe must guarantee security.
But a security measure that diminishes the guarantees of freedom is an action that denies certainty to the law and is therefore a source of insecurity and barbarity.
Guantanamo.
Europe is the homeland of rights.
The Stockholm Programme defines them in meticulous detail.

Today, a fair balance between the discipline of anticrime repression and the everyday life of citizens, their familial, social, economic, work, and study relationships—all governed by civil law and civil justice.
This is Europe of the citizen.
It must be constructed within the Member States and the Community institutions.
European society is more united, mobility more intense, than is generally believed.
Mobility is now a right.
Conflicts between states are not impermeable walls, but networks through which society filters every day.
The first is that Stockholm provides the institutional framework for judicial cooperation, mutual recognition, a European justice system, that of the national one.
It is that of the community, a European, national, and community right, a European citizen, a European judge, the national one, and the community one.

European rules are dictated by community regulations and the jurisprudence of European courts, but also originate from the behavior of workers, businesses, students, national magistrates, and European networks among justice professionals.
Bottom-up, therefore, and this is a process originating from the ground up; the Stockholm Programme seeks to support it.
Parliament has made a significant effort with this resolution, which I hope will be supported here by a broad, unified vote, one to which we have worked intensely.
The Council should respectfully take this into consideration.
Lisbon is not yet in implementation, but it is there, clearly present.
Let the Council be ambitious, Minister, value what we have elaborated here and the wealth of suggestions that emerge from it.

In this report on the budgetary control, I must acknowledge the very important work carried out by the Commission, the excellent work of the rapporteur, and I must also say something about the political cohesion.

This is because from the outset, we have aimed to deliver a very clear message: we intend to work with great rigor to guarantee transparency, correctness, and legality in the management of public funds and, consequently, in the verification of budgets.
Significant progress has been made with the Council, which initially was unwilling to respond.
I personally attest to this to the Swedish Presidency, which has always sought to demonstrate its commitment to transparency and fairness.
Therefore, we anticipate further progress from this perspective, because it is, of course, absolutely unacceptable, particularly with the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon.

I do not want the Parliament in Lisbon to lack information and news in order to verify budgets and public funds, in the interest not only of the European Union, but also of all the citizens of Europe.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, we were in Ramallah when the news arrived that Europe had adopted a new decision regarding the peace process in the Middle East.
We have witnessed the hopeful smile of the Palestinian representatives.
They were intense days of emotions and suffering, etched on the faces of children clinging to the window grates of their homes, on a street in Hebron, the ghost street that no Palestinian can cross.

The suffering of an 85-year-old woman evicted from her home, forced to sleep in the cold in a tent located in the garden of what had been her house, the suffering in the faces of those Palestinians who had built a farm with European funding, subsequently destroyed by Israeli soldiers.
Israel has the right to be an independent state, but the Palestinians, too, have the right to have a homeland, a state, a passport.
The decision of the Council of Europe represents a significant step forward, but action is needed immediately.
The conflict between Israel and Palestine is the tip of the iceberg of a larger conflict.
The last day was a visit; Israeli authorities prevented us, the European Parliament delegation, from visiting the Gaza Strip.
I believe that on this matter the High Representative, Baroness Ashton, must intervene to make the protest of democratic Europe heard.

I thank President De Rossa, who led the delegation, and all the other members of the delegation, because during the days we spent in Palestine, the vulnerable people of Palestine were able to see and hear the face and words of a Europe that defends rights and wants and must do more.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the European Union is committed to the fight against terrorism in all its dimensions.

When discussing the fight against terrorist crimes, it is necessary to ensure that fundamental rights are fully respected and that the measures adopted to combat terrorism are proportionate and effective.

The rights of the defense and fundamental procedural guarantees must therefore be fully respected by the institutions of the Union, even when defining lists of persons and entities, in this case linked to someone.

Al Qaeda, subject to restrictive measures, and it is equally essential that these measures be subject to adequate democratic and parliamentary oversight, as rightly prescribed by the Treaty of Lisbon.

It is therefore evident that, as also stated by the European Parliament’s legal service, any measure of this type will have to follow the codecision procedure, allowing the representatives of European citizens to fully perform their legislative and oversight role.
Mr. President, I would like to avoid continuing to list the reasons for our disagreement with the Iranian government.
I merely wish to highlight, having not been cited here, the fact that among the most serious violations of civil rights is that against young people.
Having signed the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child, the Iranian government continues to impose capital punishment on minors.
I would like it that, following this debate, on the one hand, Baroness Ashton commits to indicating a common line for all of Europe and for the entire European Parliament.
An European focus on the events unfolding in Iran, and, on the other hand, that the interparliamentary committee with the Iranian government takes note that a change of course is necessary.

I participated with friends Scuria and Tatarella in the protest that we had formulated against the Commission, which, in any event, declared with an official statement its intention to go to Iran, whereas we had instead insisted on the possibility of meeting the opposition and engaging in dialogue with it.

I would like the Commission, from this moment onward, to turn a new page and establish relationships of assistance, support, and dialogue with the representatives of the opposition in exile, not least Mrs. Miriam Rajavi, who represents this reality.
This is what the European Community should do, rather than sanctions.

I intervene to highlight the gravity of the deindustrialization situations affecting various Sicilian industrial hubs, particularly the automotive hub of Terni Mareese, Fiat Group, and the petrochemical hub of Gela, Eni Group.
Hampered and damaged by competition stemming from low-wage systems within some EU countries, it freezes in the face of Asian competition.
With regard to the processes of severe deindustrialization occurring within widespread areas of the Union, I believe it is time to reconsider the line of non-return.
to review the actions undertaken thus far by the European Commission and to begin implementing a package of measures to support relevant and strategic European industries.
This exhortation is primarily directed to the European Commission and to Commissioner Tajani for Industry.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the theme of fiscal good governance, although always of considerable importance, has gained even greater timeliness and significance following the major economic and financial crisis two years ago.
International, G20, and European leaders have discussed it, and continue to discuss it, particularly when addressing the fight against tax evasion and tax havens.
All of this is important, a sign of commitment and determination, but one must not harbor illusions that an announcement alone is sufficient.
A serious and consistent policy is required.
Many problems remain.
Is it truly still too easy to purchase or establish a shell company to evade taxes?
A simple search online reveals thousands of websites offering companies for acquisition, even in countries within the European Union.
Often, a single email with a scanned photocopy of the passport attached is sufficient to open a company.
It is necessary to put an end to the practice of creating fictitious legal entities to evade taxation.
This report that I present is based on the communication from the European Commission on fiscal good governance of 28 April 2009.
The report aims to advance concrete proposals and requests a strong commitment from the European Commission and the Council to implement these proposals.
It is necessary to consider the fight against tax havens, tax evasion, and the illicit flight of capital as a priority for the European Union.
From this, the principle of good governance, which is founded on transparency, information exchange, cross-border cooperation, and fair tax competition.
The point is that ever greater tax cooperation and collaboration are needed within the European Union.
The overarching objective we must set for ourselves is to achieve automatic information exchange on a global and multilateral scale, naturally beginning with the European Union.
The banking secrecy must be abolished entirely in the countries of the European Union, and an end must be put to, without further delay, the system of derogation from such agreements.
a temporary measure authorizing the application of a withholding tax at source, often evaded or underestimated, instead of information exchange.
I do not wish to elaborate on the specific proposals contained in the report.
I emphasize that we nonetheless need to address several specific points: broadening the scope of the 2003 Savings Directive, combating VAT fraud, and establishing a public Union register.
The Commission has also proposed establishing a system of oversight that takes into account individuals or companies that have created entities or opened accounts in tax havens.

It is also necessary for the European Union to speak with a single voice on the international stage, to advocate for improvements to OECD regulations to achieve automatic exchange of information, rather than exchange on request.

Commissioner Kovac, please also consider the other reports; we need a strong commitment from the Commission and we need, at this moment, for the new Commission, at the time of the handover, to have these priorities emphasized.
We will hold the Council and the European Commission accountable for their work.
I thank my colleagues, and especially the shadow rapporteurs, for the contribution they have made to this work, which I hope will be approved by Parliament.

Mr. President, I must admit that when we discuss the fight against terrorism, focusing solely on intelligence and technology, I always have the impression that we insist on examining the issue inadequately, as if we were treating an illness by concentrating only on its symptoms and not on its causes.
Is it not perhaps time to address the problem of terrorism by targeting the heart of the matter, rather than limiting ourselves to its external phenomenology?

Addressing the heart of the problem means, for example, becoming aware that terrorism is also a direct manifestation of the inability or unwillingness of ethnic groups to integrate into the European cultural fabric.
I ask and I request of this Parliament: do we want to discuss terrorism?
Let this Parliament then have the courage to politically address a debate on the degree of integration of Muslims in Europe and their willingness to share Western values, rights, and freedoms.
In this regard, I have submitted a question to the Commission regarding full-face veils to encourage this Assembly to openly address the issue.
It appears there is no willingness to address the matter.
I ask, and I put the question to you, honourable colleagues, from all political groups: if not on these topics, on what others should the political leadership of the peoples of Europe speak out?

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the closure of negotiations with Croatia by 2010 is a feasible objective, and this report serves to highlight, in a balanced manner, the progress achieved and the steps remaining to be taken.
Now it is justice that is the sector in which decisive reforms are still needed.
It is not enough, indeed, to complete the necessary systemic reforms and to approve new laws and to cooperate as needed with the Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia.
I insist on the necessity of creating a genuine legal culture and mindset in line with European standards.

The independence of the judiciary, a central issue, becomes crucial, as does the training, recruitment, and career progression of judges, meaning the absence of any kind of influence exerted by the government on the courts.
I appeal to the Commission to consider the need for decisive measures in this regard during the final phase of the negotiations.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, Croatia’s accession to the European Union accentuated the consolidation of a European identity capable of expressing the shared values of the new Europe without obscuring, but rather integrating, the specificities of its many facets.

The Republic of Croatia has made appreciable efforts to align with the required parameters, particularly in combating organized crime through new anti-mafia measures, but needs to undertake further efforts, especially within the judicial sector, before the 2010 negotiations can be concluded.

Further progress can be made by the institutions of the Republic of Croatia to align with what is provided for in the first protocol of the European Convention on Human Rights signed in Paris in 1952, by assessing the restitution of nationalized property to its legitimate owners.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, once again, recently, there has been an environmental disaster in Italy: the Lambro River and the Po River.
Recently, the Court of Justice of Luxembourg has condemned Italy for the danger to public health, for the unlawful disposal of waste, and for failing to control waste collection in Campania.
And news of these days concerning the increase in leukemia cases in Taranto linked to the Ilva steel plant, as well as the disposal of asbestos in schools in Crotone, as well as dioxin in Campania.
It is a continuous environmental disaster.

I formally request from the Commission what measures it intends to take to ensure that the Italian government complies with the standards of European Union directives, particularly concerning the Court of Justice’s ruling of the other day.
The city of Naples has been subjected to public ridicule for many weeks and many months worldwide.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, this debate is not a formality, but aims to be very concrete and to pose clear and precise questions regarding the resources and from where they will be obtained. I hope, and the Parliament hopes, that the answers will be equally clear and precise today and in the forthcoming Councils of March 12th and 25th.

We want to firmly tell the Commission and the Council that the European Union, which has raised before the world the flag of the fight against atmospheric emissions and the climate challenge, today has a duty of consistency if it does not want to lose credibility.
He must do everything possible to ensure these objectives are achieved.

We must be very clear that discussing a low-emission economy signifies a kind of Copernican revolution for the production system; it means changing many things, having clear priorities, political will, but above all, adequate resources and tools.
We also know that this Copernican revolution is essential because our production system, European industry, is to remain competitive.
I mean that in many countries, in many research centers, in many universities, the expertise is ready, the capabilities are present, the will is there; it now remains to ignite this engine.
They must do it, the Commissioner said, the Council said, the Member States must do it, businesses, private entities.
But I believe that the essential task of bringing together this complex partnership is that of the European Union.
To constructively address the employment problem, the key directives in community actions are three: react, evolve, and protect.

To react, that is, to abandon the celebratory tones of Europropaganda and address the concrete problems that plague EU citizens, ensuring a direct connection between the world of education and the needs of the market and the territory, and re-framing among young people the perception of manual trades.

To evolve, that is, to make the EU 2020 strategy a positive synthesis between the demands of businesses and those of workers, in favor of a labor market in which contractual flexibility responds to the instability of market demand.

To protect, that is, to provide employment for those who have lost it, primarily to our citizens. Member States must therefore evaluate immigration policies based on the actual need for immigration, and with 23 million unemployed, consideration should be given to blocking extra-EU immigration for a number of years.
I see no other ways to protect our work and our social system.
Concrete action, courage, and decentralization are needed.

Mr. President, this concerns an oral amendment to point 13, where it invites the Commission to verify, in the current situation, the possibility of providing verified humanitarian assistance to the situation.

Mr. President, honourable colleagues, I would like to reiterate once again the importance of the written declaration on corruption that I proposed together with four other Members of Parliament, and which a majority of the European Parliament has approved, so as to commit the Council and the Commission to truly effective legislation on corruption.

I have returned, on behalf of the budgetary control committee, from a visit to Greece, and it is certainly the case that one of the reasons for the structural crisis in Greece also depends on the squandering of public funds, a situation that also occurs in Italy.

Eroded by corruption, as evidenced in recent days, corruption that circulates primarily through the illicit management of public funds, the relationship between a segment of the political class and a segment of businesspeople and white-collar organized crime.

It is important that the European Parliament exert all of its pressure on the Commission, on the Member States, that Member States failing to comply be sanctioned, and that the European institutions responsible for controlling corruption and combating organized crime be strengthened.
Regarding masculine and feminine distinctions, we know very well that this difference is even more pronounced within the realm of autonomous activities.
Indeed, women have far too often been compelled to sacrifice their professional ambitions in the name of assuming the role and the workload that stems from absolute dedication to family.

To resolve this problem, I believe it is necessary to implement measures such as those contained in the directive we are discussing, but keeping a firm focus on the guiding star of the family. Only this can give meaning and hope of success to these very measures.

Freeing women from the distressing dilemma of choosing between the roles of mother, wife, and entrepreneur means lessening the burden of familial labor and directly addressing concrete problems through positive and specific measures to support families.
Placing the family at the center is essential; otherwise, any package of measures will be a disjointed collection of interventions, ultimately futile.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, Commissioner, we are gathered today to discuss organ transplantation, which undoubtedly represents one of the most positive aspects of progress in the healthcare field.
But it also opens up a whole series of problems concerning the rights of the donor and the patient, which must be addressed on ethical, social, legal, and economic grounds.

It is a matter of initiating a virtuous pathway that addresses the severe imbalance between needs and the quantity of organs available, without, however, infringing upon the principle of free and voluntary donation.

every form of commercialization and illegal trafficking, guaranteeing the quality and safety of organs intended for transplantation, with measures that effectively combine confidentiality with traceability.

It follows that, in a context of cross-border exchanges and significant differences between the transplantation systems adopted in the various Member States, these objectives can only be achieved by promoting coordination and cooperation.
In this regard, I believe it would be very important to establish a European database and adopt common quality and security standards.
We must, however, be careful not to introduce unnecessary forms of rigidity or create further bureaucratic burdens that compromise what is currently performed correctly and effectively.
Here, it would be not only contrary to our objectives.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I thank the rapporteur for the excellent work done on the European Union’s accession to the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights, which has reached its first agreement in two years.

It represents a benefit for European citizens, because thanks to it, there will be a new tribunal external to the European Union to ensure that the rights of European citizens are always respected by the European Union and its Member States.

In virtue of the principle of democracy, the European Union and its Member States must always have the right to defend themselves; for this reason, I believe it is fundamental that every nation adhering to the convention must have a judge to explain the context of each appeal.

I believe that the European Parliament has an informal body with the purpose of coordinating the exchange of information between the Parliament and the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council, and it is important that the Parliament is also consulted and involved in the negotiation process.
I would also add that European citizens have the right to understand the mechanisms of this accession, just as they have the right to know what their rights are.

Therefore, I believe it is fundamental that the Council of Europe and the European Union consider developing guidelines, with a clear explanation of all the effects and implications that accession will entail.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, 170 measures in five years—numbers too ambitious for a program lacking a genuine character, particularly on certain issues.
On immigration, the program beyond official documents reveals an embarrassing weakness: what is the point of promising and strengthening bodies and agencies if there is no political strategy?

A truly useful strategy must be based on several key principles: combating irregular immigration along the southern border, sharing responsibility among all European Union states regarding irregular migration, a policy of agreements with third countries, and, above all, the recognition that immigration, during times of crisis, is not an asset.
From the Parliament’s home page, we read that over 20% of young people in Europe are unemployed.
In a continent with 25 million unemployed, the Commissioner for Internal Affairs states that the issue of migration must be based on solidarity.

Instead, we must reason with concreteness and realism. Today, the priority is to provide employment for our citizens; everything else is complacent rhetoric that does not help either the integration of immigrants nor, least of all, our own people.
I wish to take this opportunity to bring to the attention of the Presidency the need for intervention to ensure that long-term connections are more effective.
Air flights between Strasbourg and European capitals should be direct and no longer create inconvenience for those who must take three or four planes to reach Strasbourg.
Please intervene appropriately.

The financial crisis of these months and years, the new Treaty of Lisbon with its new responsibilities, and the challenge we have set ourselves with Europe 2020 require the mobilization of new and substantial financial resources.
The paradox we are witnessing even in this discussion is that, as things stand, both the Commission and the Council appear silent, incapable of choosing and determining decisions.
However, we know that if we want to emerge from the difficult economic and social phase, if we want to address the major challenges of the environment, the development of cohesion policy, and the
If we wish to improve agriculture in the coming years, we have a need to invest more in Europe and in Europe's function, and therefore in the essential function of Europe, namely its budget.
Therefore, we must not be afraid to discuss, even in a phase of financial constraints, investing more in resources.
having the force and capacity to develop a debate and a discussion that places the theme of greater resources alongside the themes of greater quality and greater flexibility in their utilization.
But this is the challenge that lies before us.
Mr. President, honourable colleagues, the European Parliament is called upon, as we know, to express itself definitively on food information to consumers.
It should be stated immediately that this was objectively a laborious, lengthy, and controversial legislative process, one that could not be shortened.

It is, in fact, a matter of harmonizing Community food law through regulations designed to render information transparent to consumers, avoiding inducing them into confused or potentially harmful choices, even regarding their health.

The report by the Honourable Sommer, to whom due credit is given for synthesizing numerous requirements, therefore aims to remedy disputes and disparate information systems currently in place within the Union countries.

It is not coincidental that national regulations currently differ in the denominations describing the nature of the regulations offered for sale, creating a system that varies from country to country and fostering unfair competition to the detriment of potential consumers.
Thus, based on the European Commission’s proposal, efforts have been made to provide new direction for existing legislation, engaging both the food industry and consumers.
Concurrently, the report commits the European food industry to providing clarity on mandatory indications, the indication and presentation of nutritional values.

In a globalized market, the European Union could not avoid the necessary innovation of food product legislation, in order to better protect food trade and safeguard against increasingly invasive and unchecked international competition.

It is not new that there is more frequent discussion about the hazardousness of food products that, via telemarketing, carry remedies and indications that often do not meet the food requirements, which are nonetheless marketed as food and beneficial for human health.
Madam Commissioner, we requested this oral questioning and a parliamentary resolution to clarify with the Commission that a long-term solution is not possible.
Within the framework of the Stockholm Programme, the construction of a widespread European legal culture across the territory, on our territory, is highly important.

I should like to state immediately that this is important, but also that, in view of the communication the Commission will have to produce on future pilot projects, as has been said, we would like to clarify some concepts.
Before the consultations begin promptly, the consultations of Parliament, meanwhile, reach the initial phase, when the idea begins to take shape.
Of these future projects, so that we do not arrive too late, when the projects are already formulated quite completely.
I say this because we have some fundamental observations to make.
Considering that the national magistrate, the lawyer of individual States, is today a decisive piece in the construction of Europe.
By interpreting even national rights through a European lens, it provides the conditions for resolving conflicts and regulating the daily lives of citizens.
Thus, a European sensibility is founded in all those who live on these territories, so that they may experience firsthand and physically the rights of European citizens.
It is an advantage that the introduction of European elements into all national laws and, consequently, particularly into Community law, improves the lives of citizens.
Genuine advantages are offered to address a range of issues that would otherwise remain unresolved.
And I would like to say with this that we would like to somewhat overturn the framework.
For example, we would not agree that these projects are styled like Erasmus, because the number of magistrates and lawyers involved in Erasmus-style projects would be
very low, as it inevitably must be, due to the high costs of physical mobility in this field and therefore not particularly relevant within the overall context of the judiciary.
But the most important matter concerns the term “familiarization of courses” that we introduced in our document.

Judges are not schoolchildren sitting at desks being lectured; they are mature individuals, possessing a high level of professionalism, with limited time available for this, not easily relocated, but they bring

They must be stimulated so that this knowledge is tested against the new problems of European law and European culture, creating conditions of exchange that are predominantly virtual rather than real.
and starting not so much from a general framework, but from individual cases, from the specific problems that magistrates and lawyers face—those are the problems that citizens must confront.
that are new and that must stimulate professional growth for these legal operators, within an effectively increased impetus.
We must contribute to the reflection on their lived experiences, on what they have learned, in order to respond positively to the challenges that Europe poses.

As you can see, Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, we intend to introduce something new to the tradition of courses that have been held thus far, which we find to be scarcely effective for this purpose.

We must know how many funds are available and what to express a doubt regarding the idea, as was written in the communication, of a central European institution governing this process, because we are in favor of a grassroots movement and not instead a centralization.
This concerns a new configuration.

What we intend to convey, however, is that if a European mindset is not formed among judges and lawyers – who in this way offer their services to justice and the citizens who request it – we will not be making Europe.
Therefore, this is not just an important document for European justice; it is an important document for the entire development of European unity.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the proposal on the rights of passengers traveling by bus aims to improve and protect passengers, particularly those with disabilities or reduced mobility.
This is the first regulation on passenger rights in bus transport and should guarantee passengers, as already occurs in the rail and air sectors.
The second-reading position aims to establish a series of rights for passengers who decide to travel by bus.

I concur with the rapporteur Cancián’s line of reasoning, whom I thank for the excellent work performed, and I believe that the scope of application of the regulation should be modified, excluding regional services when they are integrated with urban and suburban services.
It would be just and necessary to guarantee passenger rights in the event of accidents, cancellations, or departure delays, as had already been decided in the first reading by Parliament.

Equally important is the matter of information regarding passenger rights. It would indeed be useful to provide passengers with information on connections with other modes of transport, which will also ensure dialogue between passenger transport services via bus and those via rail.

Regarding individuals with disabilities, those with reduced mobility should be guaranteed the utmost protection, and I would propose a 24-hour timeframe instead of 48 to request assistance, as well as greater safeguards for compensation and replacement of assistive devices used by people with disabilities in the event of loss or damage.
Furthermore, taking into account the needs of passengers with reduced mobility, any architectural barrier should be eliminated and existing infrastructure improved to ensure accessibility.
This regulation aims to enhance the competitiveness of the bus sector, promote intermodality, but above all to improve passenger travel conditions.

Mr. President, esteemed colleagues, I thank Rapporteur Sterckx, who has done an excellent job on this report concerning the extension of free movement in the maritime sector for navigation within the European Union.
I share with the rapporteur the purpose of this directive, namely to exempt all maritime transport of goods within the European Union from unnecessary administrative formalities.

Indeed, to have a borderless European maritime space, it is not only important that the various competent authorities cooperate satisfactorily, but also that the various simplification systems are applied simultaneously.
This is necessary to ensure the proper functioning of the entire European maritime space without borders, to ensure that maritime freight transport is more attractive and utilized optimally.

The harmonization of administrative procedures between Member States will allow for smoother navigation between the various ports of the European Union and will revitalize maritime freight traffic, which currently accounts for less than 10% of the total.
To date, navigation continues to be hampered by the administrative formalities imposed upon it.
Electronic systems should therefore be activated as quickly as possible, as this would facilitate a faster data exchange system.

Furthermore, interoperability is essential for achieving genuine administrative simplification; indeed, initiating information exchange via email is not entirely efficient and proves futile if the information systems are not interoperable from a technical standpoint.
As for language, I believe that the use of a common language would certainly benefit European maritime navigation.
In this way, communication would be more efficient, causing less confusion and fewer administrative delays.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I would first like to offer special congratulations to our rapporteur, the honorable Kramer, because we all know that we have achieved a result that sometimes seemed unexpected.
I would like to recall that this dossier was indeed considered a dossier at risk of conciliation proceedings.
Therefore, we have also heard from the Commissioner’s words, and it is evident to all that we are facing a complex undertaking that has required considerable time.
Just to think that we’re dealing with a directive from 1996, and this work leads us to the fifth and most important amendment of the industrial emissions directive.
These few data points alone, I believe, reveal all the shortcomings and even the defects of this legislation.

I would like to recall that a directive of difficult implementation concerns nine Member States affected by infringement proceedings and possesses such a broad scope as to be, at times, even inappropriate.

Here, all of this—we must not conceal it—has entailed significant effort, has required renunciations from all institutions involved, from all political groups, from all national delegations, and has frequently presented us with truly difficult choices.

However, I am here this evening to state with conviction that, in my opinion, we have achieved the best possible results in safeguarding competition, protecting the environment, and supporting European industrial and employment policy.
We truly have, on the one hand, a directive that imposes common obligations on all Member States, but on the other, a directive that also allows for the flexibility that is necessary.

I sincerely hope that the results of this restructuring will, in the immediate term, include a reduction in administrative burdens, and in the medium term, an improvement in environmental performance and a strengthening of European industry.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I would like to underscore the situation in which the Church finds itself facing a reality to which, for too long, due importance has not been attributed.
that is, the instability in Central Asia, which unfortunately is growing, while hopes for democracy and economic progress, at least in some of these countries, prove to be particularly fragile.

Kyrgyzstan has suffered in the last month from extremely harsh clashes that will leave, at least in the immediate future, a legacy of interethnic hatred that will make the country's stabilization even more difficult than it was previously.

The task of the international community and the European Union in particular, as has already been stated, is to assist Kishida as much as possible under three aspects through immediate aid for the victims.

Second, through long-term economic assistance, as far as the European Union is concerned, within the framework of the strategy for growth and development, the European Union must be able to effectively contribute to supporting growth needs and growth.

strategy for Central Asia and the instruments implemented in that context, through political support to underpin the process of returning to constitutional legality and the realization of a genuine rule of law.
The constitutional referendum, held in crisis from 28 June under obviously very difficult conditions, can be considered a first step on the road back to a constitutional order.

The electoral process of June 28th, among other things, received a positive assessment from the OSCE observation mission, which naturally took into account the special conditions under which the referendum was held.
The new constitutional order of the Church will be more oriented towards a parliamentary system than towards a presidential one.
This may allow for a better consideration of the country’s varied ethnic composition and the necessity of gathering consensus from the diverse components of a country so fractured and composed.
The European Union and Kyrgyzstan are linked by a partnership and cooperation agreement, which stipulates regular meetings of a parliamentary cooperation committee.
It is our hope that our interparliamentary exchanges can resume as soon as possible with the participation of a Parliament democratically elected and duly constituted.
In the immediate term, the cricket farmer, as already mentioned, needs stability and our political-economic support; we seek not to be stingy with either.
Mr. President, honourable colleagues, the European Council, which no one has voted for, today we also have a rotating presidency held by a government of no confidence from its own citizens.

This alone would suffice to understand why Europe is experiencing a profound crisis, an Europe that has become a political paradox in the hands of a political elite in whom citizens no longer recognize themselves.
The Belgian non-presidency programme discusses structural reforms, job growth, financial stability, and competitiveness, and the chosen instrument would be the EU 2020 strategy.
The current crisis, however, should prompt Europe to adopt ingredients quite different from those that led to failure.

A comprehensive reassessment is necessary, because the crisis is not a reflection of decline, but rather a death certificate for the European social model that Euro-propaganda would instead administer as a cure.
Today, Europe is a vast edifice collapsing upon itself under the weight of democracy, centralism, and obstacles to free enterprise.
To emerge from the crisis, Europe must change its vocabulary: more decentralization, less bureaucracy, more concreteness, and attention to the real problems of citizens.
Everything else will only inexorably accelerate the decline.

I would like to emphasize in this intervention of mine how the progressive erosion of European farmers' incomes, at the expense of increasing problems in agriculture and farming, represents an opportunity for the future.

The profit margins within the agro-industrial supply chain are creating a concerning economic marginalization of those employed in the agricultural sector, with resulting relinquishment of their activities.
Therefore, a change of course is required, one that the European Commission itself acknowledges and that the report under examination in the Chamber this morning confirms.
The Chamber's approval this morning, to which I wish to express my support, underscores with extensive justifications and suggestions, including legislative and sectoral ones.
It is, in fact, necessary to combat global commodity speculation and ensure supply security.

Furthermore, greater price transparency must be ensured, which will not only do justice to the agricultural producers but also correct the significant power imbalances currently in place and prevent abuses among the various operators.
Agriculture must reaffirm itself as a sector of economic and social stability and regain influence within the mercantile context of the European Union.
Mobilism and myopia—this is the diagnosis of the malaise afflicting today’s European Union of 27.

Stagnation, because if one in four young people in Italy is unemployed and 16 million unemployed individuals are counted within the Eurozone, it is also because the noise of Eurozone propaganda over recent months has not been followed by any genuinely effective action.

Myopia, because in indicating the way out of the crisis, Europe not only presented the usual recipe, but completely lost sight of the most authentically territorial dimension of economic and social cohesion policy.

Only by placing the territory at the center of political action, only by respecting its unique cultural vocations, can European policies for development and employment restart, drawing sustenance from those natural energies that every geographic area expresses—districts, small and medium-sized enterprises, and artisanal crafts.
To address the employment problem, one must first think small, investing in local entities and prioritizing subsidiarity, while safeguarding a heritage of linguistic and cultural diversity.
If the needle of European Brussels does not guide its policy towards the territory, the shipwreck of the Europroject is a certainty.
Mr. President, in the construction of a Europe of rights, a central place is held by freedom of information, pluralism of information, and independence of information.
The Commissioner, the Commissioneress, noticed that there is a country of the European Union, moreover a founding member, with the Treaty of Rome of the European Union, where there is not
It is the pluralism of information, where a Prime Minister directly or indirectly controls public and private television and the press.
What democratic electoral competition is possible in a country where a president, the Council, and a political party control the media?
What democracy can exist in a country where a law is about to be passed that prevents journalists from publishing judicial news?
Forget Watergate, forget the press as guardian of the regime, pampered lapdog—what democratic country is it where the internet is sought to be brought under control?
What democratic country is this, where anyone who opposes the prevailing viewpoint is marginalized, and freedom of thought and dissent are not guaranteed?

We are not describing the Sudan of Bokassa, the Romania of Ceaușescu, and the Italy of Berlusconi, where this unfortunately happens, also because the European Commission lacks the courage to assert an autonomous and independent position vis-à-vis the Member States.
The completion of the internal market for postal services by the end of this year is an important, yet crucial, step for growth.

It would be appropriate for the Commission to conduct an impact assessment, as several colleagues preceding me have pointed out, regarding the opening of the postal market, in order to better understand the needs of citizens.

How does the Commission intend to protect the right of European citizens living in areas that are difficult to reach, such as mountainous or rural zones, to receive mail regularly, and what instruments does the Commission intend to adopt to ensure this occurs?
I also believe that this directive, which already exists, should not be exploited to justify the issue of social dumping.
It is the Member States that must implement the directive and they all possess the tools to do so.
Madam President, Madam Commissioner, colleagues, today's debate on readmission agreements cannot evade the now thorny issue concerning the agreement between the European Union and Libya.
We know that one aspect of the agreement is centered on combating irregular immigration.
We are concerned because, to date, the Commission has told us very little about it, despite the Treaty of Lisbon obliging the Commission itself to inform Parliament in a timely manner.
Libya, as is well known, has not ratified the Geneva Conventions on Human Rights, nor has it, to date, demonstrated conduct consistent with international law.

I think of the case of Eritrean immigrants detained inhumanely in the Libyan Brak detention center, or still of the closure of UNHCR offices, but I think above all of what happened last week, when a Libyan Republic patrol boat opened fire on a boat headed towards Libya.

A most serious justification, leading us to believe that the agreement signed between Libya and Italy, which resulted in an invasion of Libya, was an act of violence against an Italian fishing vessel from the port of Mazara del Vallo, present in international waters.

It also foresees the rejection of immigrants to Libya without provisions regarding the right to request asylum and individual case-by-case examinations of each situation, and includes the possibility of using firearms to stop immigrants.

Given that, in this instance as well, part of the agreement is confidential, I wonder whether the Commission is aware of its content, and whether, even if it does not deem it necessary, in this specific case, to request explanations regarding the substance of this agreement.

It is an opportunity to recall the possibility for Libyan authorities to open fire on vessels if there is suspicion that they are transporting irregular migrants, because if that were the case, such a provision would be ineffective.

Economically, it is beneficial for Europe to deepen trade relations with rapidly growing neighboring countries; however, the EU has always, at least in principle, pursued a trade policy towards third countries taking into account social and humanitarian aspects.
We must therefore assert these clauses with firm resolve toward Turkey, a country that is undergoing re-Islamization and in which the condition of women is progressively deteriorating, with more than
We have seen the women killed in 2009 in cases of domestic violence, a country where Christians live in fear of attacks by Islamist extremists.

In the report, Parliament encourages Turkey to assume a leading role in promoting fair and open trade. One thing is certain: we must be concerned about the political leadership role Turkey is seeking to carve out for itself in the Arab world and its

The friendship Turkey is cultivating with Iran and groups like Hamas. In any case, if trade policy must be, let it be, but this must never become the Trojan horse to facilitate Turkey's entry into Europe.
Mr. President, esteemed colleagues, Commissioner, this measure aims to strengthen and rationalize the European Union's pharmacovigilance system.
These are the ambitious aims and objectives set forth by the McAvan amendments, modifying, respectively, Regulation 726 and Directive 2001.
This was made possible thanks to close and efficient coordination between the Council and the European Parliament, as well as the parliamentary committees competent for the subject matter.
to arrive at discussing today a proposal that aims to improve the Community pharmacovigilance system and to refine the substantial and multi-decennial activity of the European Union in this sector.

Simplification, transparency, and rationalization can be considered the key points of these two reports, which propose measures aimed at ensuring the best possible protection of public health based on harmonized standards across Europe.

Reference is made, in fact, to a broad range of interventions that extend from a more precise definition of roles and responsibilities of the principal national and supranational stakeholders involved, to a new and more consciously active engagement of the patient, to whom the Commission addresses itself.

The Commission recognizes a fundamental role in strengthening the transparency of information regarding the safety of medicines, simplifying the activities of communication, registration, and evaluation of presumed adverse effects.
The current pharmacovigilance system must also be improved through closer collaboration at the European, national, and regional levels.
Effective participation at all three of these levels will indeed ensure a fruitful exchange of information regarding the adverse reactions of medicines.
The new pharmacovigilance system will be able to ensure a high level of shared and secure information to benefit patients, national authorities, and healthcare professionals.
Precisely during these days, here in Brussels, the final sessions of this Parliament have taken place.

Many representatives from municipalities and regions have discussed how to address the serious problems facing the lives of our cities, the old and new needs affecting workers, families, and small and large productive businesses.
The economic crisis that has befallen our societies has made it harder and more difficult for everyone to provide adequate responses to a new serious social issue.
In this context, I believe that everyone understands that cohesion policy has, on many occasions, been the only concrete tool available to territories in attempting to provide responses.
Therefore, we can state that cohesion policy has, in recent years, served as an essential lever for the process of European integration for all regions.
Now we find ourselves redefining this policy for the period after 2013; we are therefore at a turning point.
For this reason, it is vital to avoid certain risks.
The first fundamental principle is that of its own renationalization, which would represent a serious step backward.

Subsequently, it is necessary to ensure, in the construction of the financing plan, adequate provision for both the needs of the most vulnerable entities and, simultaneously, the ability to avoid penalizing the most competitive and advanced regions.
Finally, it is essential to streamline procedures for those who have demonstrated efficiency and to strengthen the ability to sanction those who have not.
We expect the Commission to move in this direction.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the road to a Europe tailored to women is still long and difficult.
The statistics speak clearly: the global crisis has struck the labor market, severely testing female employment, which in 2008 decreased further by 0.7 percentage points.

Despite the provocations regarding equal opportunities and employment that periodically fill an EU propaganda campaign geared towards securing consensus, to date, no concrete measures have been adopted to ensure women achieve true fulfillment as both worker and mother.
The Europe of the future needs to radically rethink its welfare model and not simply change its label periodically.

Therefore, the directive that aligns maternity leave across Europe is welcome, but inefficient is the decision to treat, at the margins of this subject, the complementary and equally important matter of paternity leave within the same report.

Greater integration of women is not merely a moral value, but also a strategic objective for the sustainability of the much-touted European social model, which continues not to convince me due to the lack of results.

Mr. President, esteemed colleagues, esteemed colleagues, esteemed colleagues, esteemed colleagues, esteemed colleagues, esteemed colleagues, esteemed colleagues, esteemed colleagues, esteemed colleagues, esteemed colleagues, esteemed colleagues.

I thank you for the work completed with your customary, I must say, punctuality, and for the quality of your proposals, which have garnered the favorable, I would say unanimous, opinion of the development committee.
Regarding what I will say, but especially concerning what my colleague Michel has done to date, I am convinced that the report can be voted on with a large majority.
But I will now turn to the discussion.
During 2009, the European Commission presented a proposal to amend Regulation 1905, which establishes a financial instrument for development cooperation.
With this proposal, the Commission had requested that Parliament approve an amendment allowing non-governmental organizations to benefit from tax advantages when operating in developing countries.
Proposal accepted by us.
But the cooperation and development regulations also contain the implementing rules for the European Union’s development policy.
These rules stipulate that when the Commission must allocate funding, it is required to follow comitology procedures.

This means that Parliament has the power to examine these funding proposals and, should the Commission exceed its remit, Parliament can then adopt resolutions to request the Commission to alter the decisions in question.

Only since 2006 has Parliament considered, in at least twelve cases, that the Commission had exceeded its implementing powers, but in only three of those cases has the Commission actually modified or withdrawn its decision proposal.
Following the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, the Development Committee proposed applying the procedure for delegated acts provided for in Article 290 of the Treaty of Lisbon.
The adoption of these procedures would mean that, at least in strategic funding decisions that the European Commission must adopt, Parliament would have a more significant role.
Indeed, according to the Treaty of Lisbon, in certain, well-defined cases, the Parliament may delegate to the Commission the power to make strategic decisions, but what might these decisions be?
In our view, the selection of countries to which the European Union should provide development assistance

It is a choice that rests with the legislature, and then to which sectors should priority be given in funding: education, healthcare, environmental protection, the capacity for good governance, the development of small businesses?
And how can transparency be ensured in the management of development aid?
These are the areas and subjects in which the European Parliament should play a more significant role than it has in the past.
It is here that the legislature must provide precise guidance to the executive.
And it is precisely this the direction in which, I believe, the requests of European citizens ultimately converge.
I genuinely hope for the widest possible consensus on this report by the Honourable Mitchell.
The paper was presented to the supervisor.

Integrated maritime policy requires moving beyond the phase of good intentions and providing renewed impetus to a strategy that will serve as a catalyst for growth and development of the European Union, addressing the enormous deficits accumulated in the prevention of environmental disasters, the fight against climate change, and the combating of pollution.
Just this morning, our colleague Pirillo called the Parliament's attention to yet another catastrophic event that occurred in recent days in the city of Paola, Calabria.

The Commission must demonstrate concrete action, operating not only with governance tools but also implementing specific legislative measures, drawing the necessary lessons from past errors, errors resulting from an approach often too sectorial.

There is full awareness that this process is very complex, but we are in the midst of a difficult and demanding crossing, one that cannot tolerate lapses in attention and requires adequate investment.
governance mechanisms, both at the inter-institutional level and in international cooperation for regional basins, among which the Mediterranean stands out due to the complexity of its jurisdiction.
It is for this fundamental reason that understanding the management of the Mediterranean basin as a shared heritage of all riparian states is essential, based on the principle of the

Conversely, the increasingly common practice of unilaterally declaring exclusive economic zones or similar areas in the Mediterranean Sea, in addition to being inconsistent with the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea, would undermine the concept of effective and shared governance.

I recall, in this regard, that just a month ago this interpretation by Libya resulted in a veritable armed assault against an European fishing vessel, and it would be mistaken to assert that this is solely an Italian-Libyan affair.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I thank Honorable Meissner for the report on integrated maritime policy. I concur with the rapporteur on the necessity of strengthening maritime transport and shipbuilding, and of safeguarding coastal regions, as well as promoting innovation and research activities.
Today, maritime transport plays a fundamental role in the commercial sphere.
Therefore, cooperation between small and large ports facing the same maritime basin should be encouraged, facilitating a more fluid exchange of trade.
Furthermore, to ensure intermodality, it is necessary to invest in port and hinterland infrastructure, particularly that of ports which can be connected to European corridors.
Finally, I believe it is important not to overlook another theme, namely that of port security.

It is necessary that there be a homogenization of all security measures within all European ports, in order to better safeguard maritime transport and to prevent unfair competition at the expense of those ports that, in order to ensure greater security, must face higher expenses.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, 30 years ago Morocco denied for many years that there was a war with the Sahrawi people, and today it is denying that there is a disproportionate repression against the same people.
Yet, in Western Sahara, there are deaths and injuries among a population that claims only the right to live in freedom in their own land.
Morocco has effectively closed its borders to anyone who might bear witness to these events.
No information and no representatives.
A French deputy and our colleague Mayer were denied access.
Europe watches passively.
There is no indication in the Commission’s communication that places us in a subordinate position to the mediation of the UN, which continues to fail as it has for the past thirty years.
There is no statement from Ms. Ashton, who is responsible for foreign policy.
It is necessary to react with a statement of position from Parliament.
It is necessary to react toward Morocco, interrupting every initiative concerning trade agreements, beginning with the renewal of fishing agreements.

Mr. President, honourable colleagues, my contribution is not intended to be the usual Eurosceptic rhetorical exercise, but an impetus for the EU to pay more attention to substance than form and to abandon propaganda in favour of concrete action.
Having failed the Lisbon Strategy, Europe crafted the new EU 2020 slogan, but in reality, it offered no innovative responses to employment challenges.

The data confirms it: 9.6, the unemployment rate in Europe, 20.2 for young people. In Italy, the third net contributor to the EU budget, the situation for young people is even more dramatic, with 25.9% of young individuals without employment.

In the Europe I envision, there are no wasted resources in promotional campaigns, but rather efficient investments to ensure that training programs prepare professionals for sectors within the internal market, where concrete employment opportunities exist.
I conclude by reiterating the importance of investing in professional training, a symbol of excellence for our territories.
The world of crafts offers a unique potential for employment and a wealth of knowledge, upon which the task of sustaining the competitiveness of the European system must rest.

Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, Madam Prime Minister, the European resolve to establish ambitious goals in view of the next climate change conference is certainly a commitment to be pursued with tenacity and with the awareness that the results will condition the future of our planet.
But it is precisely for this reason, dear colleagues, that we must be realistic and more cautious in our expectations.

International negotiations in preparation for the Cancun Conference, as far as we know, have not only failed to register appreciable progress towards a global agreement, but have confirmed distrust and resistance regarding the commitments undertaken in Copenhagen.
It has already been cited, but I would like to cite China here as well.
China allows itself, for example, an increase of 5 billion tons of CO2 by 2020, with consequences that could be offset.
And perhaps not even that, but an attempt at compensation solely through a 100% reduction of European industrial emissions by the same year, by 2020.

This data not only renders the proposal for an unconditional 30% reduction—one to which we strongly object—poisonous, but also leads many independent observers to hypothesize a significant increase in global emissions by that date as well.

In this contradictory situation, it would be at the very least imprudent and even demagogic to hypothesize figures and sketch out suggestive, yet unrealistic, scenarios, where uncertainties inevitably reflect on the dimension of costs.

The hope is that the European Union will bring to Cancun a shared, realistic, and sustainable proposal, because an agreement that delivers concrete and perceptible results is always and in any case preferable to a long-term agreement.
