the expectations inevitably destined to fail and to render increasingly less credible in the eyes of the international public, this indeed would be damage difficult to repair, the efforts of governments on major environmental issues.

Mr. President, honourable colleagues, I have but one regret this evening as we discuss the Sahrawi people only because the Moroccans have invaded the Tendopoli outside El Aaiún, and this is a regret for democracy in this Parliament.
Parliament should have independently developed the will to discuss this matter, which has been festering for thirty years on international tables.
This is the most relevant political datum.
We were compelled by acts of violence, not because we autonomously decided to ensure human rights.
Why, what is it if not respect for human rights, the fact that there must be a referendum there for self-determination?

It is precisely because Morocco is our friend, because Morocco is a strong element in the relationship, that we must forcefully request, with all subsequent actions, that there be a will no longer postponable.

We must strive to build the conditions so that the mission, meticulous and contained, Mr. President, is not solely responsible for building the conditions of a referendum that is constantly postponed.
We must seek to use all the means at the disposal of the European Union to influence this event and to ensure that the referendum does justice to thirty years of suffering endured by a people.
Mr. President, apart from this matter, apart from this matter, I wished to raise a question for the Presidency.
I believe that someone still does not fully understand what the role of the European Parliament is after the Treaty of Lisbon.

I am compelled to raise a fundamental issue here: Commissioner Callas for Transport repeatedly refuses to meet with the board of Sky and Space to discuss the SESAR project, which concerns everyone from an economic, environmental, and safety perspective.

I invite the Presidency to convene Commissioner Kallas in the Chamber and to explain what programme she intends to pursue in this sector, which is extremely delicate and important for the European Parliament.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the report under discussion certainly contains positive elements; the overall orientation is towards the simplification of procedures and the streamlining of bureaucratic steps for third-country workers with a regular residence permit in a Member State.

However, just as a point of reflection, I would like to recall that today in Europe tens of millions of citizens, including many young people, are without work due to structural deficiencies in the European production system and as a result of a crisis that does not seem to be ending.

Even before considering the situation of third-country nationals residing in our countries, it is imperative that Europe commit to implementing economic, political, and social measures that primarily assist our own citizens in finding or regaining employment.
If Europe is capable of providing employment for its citizens, it will create solid social foundations for adequately managing migration flows from abroad.
The watchword must be, above all, to make Europe grow on its own feet and with its own strength.
And then there are the problems for our countries.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, to date, access to employment is regulated only for specific categories of citizens of third countries.
Not all individuals benefit from the general principle of equal treatment in access to employment.

In this context, the European Union must act to ensure fair treatment both for third-country nationals legally residing within Member States and for beneficiaries of refugee status or of international protection status, as per Directive 83 of 29 April 2004.

It is necessary to avoid a growing demand, for example, for seasonal personnel simply because they are paid less or because they incur different, lower costs compared to a European citizen recruited for the same work.

It is necessary to avoid, for example, the risk that many multinational corporations relocate their headquarters to countries like Morocco or Turkey and send their employees to work in European subsidiaries because it is more economical.
For reasons of social justice, ensuring equal treatment of European citizens in terms of remuneration, working conditions, and social security is essential.
For this reason, I believe it is right that seasonal workers, those posted, refugees, and self-employed workers be included in this directive.
Making distinctions will become extremely dangerous.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, according to estimates from international organizations and law enforcement agencies, human trafficking is now the second most lucrative source of profit globally for organized crime, after drug trafficking.
It is estimated that approximately 30 million people are victims of organ trafficking, prostitution, and forced labor.

This means that, first and foremost, the fight against this criminal phenomenon of vast proportions is a battle for the safety of our citizens, against clandestine activities, against crime that generates crime.
Faced with a phenomenon of these proportions, Europe must justly implement drastic measures against those who exploit human beings in various forms.
For this reason, in the fight against this phenomenon, cooperation between member states and between law enforcement agencies is necessary, but above all, the certainty of punishment for traffickers.

They are not exploited because they do not find dignified living conditions in their countries of origin; they live in poverty and despair and are prepared to do anything to leave their homeland for the promise of a better life, a promise that will ultimately not materialize.

Europe, therefore, in addition to preventing crime and protecting victims of trafficking, must commit more fully and with greater care to ensuring that these individuals can find acceptable living conditions in their home countries.
We must help them in their own homes; this should be the guiding principle of European political action, so that our efforts are directed not only at repression, but also at prevention.
It’s a bit too much.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, as Vice-Chair of the Development Committee, I am engaged with the challenges facing many countries, particularly in the African region, where human rights are regularly violated, trampled upon, if not at times even forgotten.

I returned just last Sunday from an official mission to the Democratic Republic of the Congo, where, in addition to the customary institutional meetings, I wanted to meet with representatives of NGOs operating in the country and visit some of the centers where they work.
I met the victims in a country where rape is conceived as a tool of war, where armed groups continue to attack women and children.
to repeatedly practice mass rapes and other systematic crimes against civil society, especially against women, the elderly, and children.
I wanted to mention the example of the Democratic Republic of the Congo because it has been a very recent, as I was saying, extremely recent experience of mine.
But the appeal I wish to make is directed, in general, to the necessity of a strong and continuous condemnation of the brutal violations of women’s rights.
The international community must significantly strengthen funding for initiatives protecting women and addressing other forms of violence.
violence, including female genital mutilation, even though it constitutes a serious violation of women’s human rights and physical integrity.

Mr. President, honourable colleagues, the European heritage brand is of fundamental importance for a continent that encompasses the majority of UNESCO sites and which, due to its significance, is important.
Finally, it highlights those natural, archaeological, urban, and culturally significant sites that have played an important role in the history, culture, and integration of the European Union.
The approval of a trademark is an important step in the process of European Union cohesion and is also educational and formative for cultural dialogue.

It can also be observed how this choice is a favorable omen for future generations, who will increasingly possess a shared vision of the European heritage that can historically and culturally enrich them.

I thank you for the speaker’s efforts and extend my sincerest congratulations for the negotiations conducted with the Commission for the effective success of this initiative, so important for the future of environmental preservation.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, neurodegenerative diseases, including Alzheimer's disease among them, represent a public health priority for the European Union.
The disease in question has serious implications, not only for the health of those who experience it.
However, the costs that must be borne for direct care and informal care are significantly higher.
Alzheimer's disease, in fact, does not solely affect those who are afflicted by it, but also involves all those who care for these patients.

It is therefore necessary to have a European response to the problem, a global coordination among Member States, a synergy of concerted actions primarily concerning the scientific and research fields, and which takes charge of the

enhancement of prevention, diagnosis, and refinement of available treatments, including innovative ones, as well as the dissemination of information among States regarding the results achieved within incremental, citizen-level advancements in disease awareness.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the situation is that Campania, particularly the city of Naples, are now universally and, unfortunately, every night, known throughout the world, and the European Union has had to address this issue on numerous occasions.

Faced with this paradoxical situation, now reminiscent of a third-world country, I therefore ask the Commission what consequences Italy will face from the standpoint of Community law and what economic sanctions will eventually be imposed on Italy should the waste crisis in the countryside not find a definitive solution in the near term.

I would also like to ask whether the Commission can provide detailed data regarding European funds that have been managed to date by the Campania region for the creation of an integrated waste collection and disposal system.
See, Commissioner, usually when we speak of emergency, we speak of dramatic, extreme situations, which nevertheless find a solution within a reasonable timeframe.
When a so-called emergency has lasted for more than 15 years, evidently something is not working.
The Italian government in recent years has sought to do everything possible to resolve the long-standing issue of waste collection and disposal cycles.
The blame is primarily attributable to the local authorities, specifically those in Campania, and their total inability or unwillingness to work towards finding a solution.

It is clear and beyond any doubt that the conditions in which Naples and Campania find themselves are due to the inaction that has characterized, for many years, the municipality, province, and region in the management of the waste cycle.
If differentiated waste collection, the primary indispensable element of a functioning waste management plan, is not properly implemented, it cannot be the fault of the central government.

If the Italian government had to dispatch the military, it happened a few weeks ago, but on other occasions previously, to replace hundreds of untrained individuals who suddenly and simultaneously fell ill, it clearly cannot be the fault of the central government.

If the emergency has struck Naples, while in the rest of Italy things are going very differently—for example, in my region, the Veneto, where fruit harvesting has been carried out for years without problems and with an extremely high cycle rate—it means that the responsibility for the emergency falls

on Campania’s politics and local administrators, and above all on the serious collusion with organized crime, which has always sought and obtained enormous profits from the waste management business thanks to the Camorra's infiltration of politics and local administrations.
Following the lies of the Berlusconi government, which took office in 2008 telling Italians that the waste problem had been resolved, the European Union is doing well.
to freeze funds to Italy until a sustainable waste management cycle is presented, based on waste recycling and composting.

It is certainly not the plan presented by President Caldoro that once again relies on uncontrolled landfills, such as those of Chiaiano, Taverna del Re, and Terzigno, even within the Parco nazionale del Vesuvio, nor on incinerators that produce death, tumors, or a genuine public health emergency.

Public funds deployed in the field, during the environmental emergency of these thirteen years, have consolidated criminal relationships between politicians—both left- and right-leaning—entrepreneurs, and the Camorra.

And in environmental matters, solutions are pursued through the criminalization of dissent, the criminalization of local communities, families, and the territory, as the Italian government has done, utilizing misinformation to suppress those who defend nature and the land.

A refugee under international law is a person who, fearing persecution for reasons of race, religion, nationality, social group, or political opinion, is outside the country of which they are a national.
Cesare Battisti is not a political persecutee.

Despite the protection afforded for years by France, we are discussing a serial killer, perpetrator or instigator of four murders, who has hidden behind the pretext of political struggle to escape a life sentence.
It is shameful for a great country like Brazil to deny extradition to a criminal who has never expressed remorse, while granting him refugee status.
Italian and especially the families of the victims demand to see this criminal brought to justice.
Faced with President Lula’s assertiveness in prohibiting extradition, the EU cannot leave the Italian government alone.

Europe has and must use all the diplomatic tools at its disposal to ensure that Italy obtains the handover of Battisti, even if it means threatening the suspension of cooperation agreements with Brasília.
to provide concrete support to the Tunisian people and its transitional government, to revitalize a Euro-Mediterranean dialogue that has been severely neglected in recent years.
The eruption of anger among the young and the poor of the Maghreb and Egypt stems from the inequitable distribution of wealth and the restrictions on the exercise of fundamental freedoms.

North Africa is ablaze and demanding more democracy, more economy, more participation, more work, and looks with astonishment at the old European continent, immobile, incapable of grasping the social transformations that have occurred in that area and of developing genuine policies of progress and peace.
Europe should pay more attention to human rights and democracy, promote more dialogue, more collaboration, and more substantive economic interventions.
Europe must open its doors and its heart to North Africa in order to make the Mediterranean a sea of peace.
Enough with the rejection of immigrants and, through the violent collaboration of countries like Libya, more investment, more welcoming policies, more aid, more Euro-Mediterranean policy.
History demands it of us.
The resolution approved today by a majority regarding the waste emergency in Campania is a very important signal.
The Campania emergency has become a European emergency and is a decision in favor of the citizens of Campania.

We say no to the expansion of funds that simply serve to consolidate corrupt politicians, unscrupulous entrepreneurs, and the Camorra; we say yes to European funds if a credible plan is presented, a credible plan.

A waste management plan compatible with the environment, no to uncontrolled dumping in national parks, no to incinerators that produce dioxin, yes instead to recycling and environmentally compatible forms.
And objection is also raised to the criminalization of local communities’ dissent, therefore, affirmation of legality.

It is a significant turning point, a warning to the Berlusconi government and to the regional government led by Caldoro, which until now have done nothing but talk and consolidate the cracks and the Mafia-affiliated bourgeoisie.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the issue of counterfeit medicines is one that is having an increasingly broad impact at both the international and community levels, both due to the increase in the number of cases and the improvement in their sophistication.
It is to these challenges that the Honourable Mathias's report seeks to respond, the result of lengthy and arduous negotiations.
The report, to which we have expressed our support, has defined a regulatory framework that, starting from more precise and detailed definitions, has taken into account the needs of each country.
We must address all actors, moments, and resignations within the pharmaceutical supply chain—security, traceability, obligations for the distribution chain—achieving a reasonable compromise.
These are some of the aspects on which it is necessary to work to achieve the initial objective of establishing stricter rules, to avert the entry of new workers.
of falsified medicines, leading to a positive and more comprehensive regulatory framework capable of safeguarding the health of citizens, protecting them from the risk of serious consequences.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, Egypt, from the virtual square on Facebook to the real one, with millions of people demanding a more equitable distribution of wealth, more justice, protesting against corruption.

From the transition of soldiers and armed personnel, it is necessary to move to a true democracy: a new constitution, new elections, abolition of the death penalty, more humane prisons, social rights, and freedoms.
It will be difficult.
Lurking are those who, in the name of an idea, think to use every means.
We wish to believe in the marvelous Egyptian people who, however, have never experienced democracy.

We desire a secular democracy, with a clear separation between religious power and political power, a democracy that integrates minorities and realizes true rights: public healthcare, social security, employment.
Europe, sustain this path, investing, however, in resources capable of fostering the genuine development of Egypt—never again dictatorships, never again poverty, never again destitution.
Mr. President, Commissioner, I believe that the issues related to the Mediterranean have, with this measure, initiated a phase even more compelling than the actions we have undertaken.
I believe that the act we are embedding today is far more important than, for the purposes of Community regulations, that of 2006.

I believe this also addresses some limitations of that regulation, which, being unilateral, has led many sectors of fishing to often maintain the idea that Europe is doing its part, but other coastal countries do not.
I believe it is strategic for us to address the topic in this dimension and with these characteristics.
The work carried out by colleague Rivellini, which has been widely shared, I believe merits a formal acknowledgement in this setting.
Nevertheless, I have a distinct feeling that the fact that we are unable to resolve this matter in the first reading and will proceed to the second reading
The opinion, particularly regarding the interpretation of Article 28 of this regulation, raises a point on which Parliament took the Commission’s side on this occasion.

Parliament essentially states that it is desirable for these delegated acts to be the responsibility of the Commission, and there is a certain resistance on the part of the Council; moreover, today’s absence is also a significant one.

But this action ensures that the idea has matured within Parliament that maintaining biodiversity, maintaining the fish stocks of this important sea, is also this operation the future of the fishermen.
Having said that, I believe that the phase we face must once again place the idea of codecision centrally.
These delegated acts have a reason for being delegated and therefore conferred today upon the Commission, but international agreements must maintain Parliament’s role firmly when they occur.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, in my opinion, we have two problems in this matter: one concerns the method, and the other concerns the substance.

The matter of method is that we are proceeding through an expedient for which we thank Honorable Fraga, namely the oral question, to discuss something that should, after the Lisbon Treaty, be a right of this Parliament.
I believe that this practice must end and we cannot resort to a strategy to accompany a co-decision process.
Codecision is such when it is nurtured in the phases in which it matures.
Today we are holding this debate; the treaty concludes, and it will proceed, and we will say yes or no at the end.
Indeed, this method needs to be reconceptualized.

Regarding this matter, however, I simply wished to emphasize—being in agreement with many points raised by my colleagues—the measurement of the effects of fishing agreements, so that they are not merely commercial agreements through which we go to purchase cephalopods at one euro per kilogram in Mauritania.

These must be able to measure both sustainability, but above all, the impact on the economy of that country; to understand how many employed individuals are affected, to determine the existing rate of innovation for artisanal fishing, to understand the utilization of these resources.
Not merely a pure and simple commercial exchange, but a fishing agreement with all its implications.
The favorable vote cast for the report by Honourable Rivasi is the result of an assessment of the management of the H1N1 influenza.
2001, which is 2009, aiming to establish general conduct criteria valid in any future global health emergency situations.
The report, following a long and positive phase of revision, places cooperation, independence, and transparency as its core principles.

It aspires to greater and better cooperation between the health authorities of Member States and European institutions, so as to be able to develop a harmonized and coordinated risk management approach.
The objectives are the demonstration of the strategy of the Member States regarding national plans for managing influenza, including vaccine stockpiles, and the publication of names of individuals.
expert institutions consulted by European health authorities and an efficient relationship of trust with the media responsible for disseminating public health messages.
That is why it received our favorable vote.

Mr. President, honourable colleagues, until today, the recommendations adopted by the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean have been incorporated into Community legislation provisionally, through annual fishing possibilities regulations.
These pertain to conservation, management, exploitation, control, and marketing measures for fishery and aquaculture products in the Mediterranean.
The permanent nature of these recommendations, however, requires a more stable legal instrument for their incorporation into Community law.
It is therefore appropriate to receive the recommendations in question through a single legislative act, to which future recommendations may be added.
Today, we have done this, and it will improve legal certainty, while simultaneously representing an important step toward simplification.
At this point, the contracting parties of the CGMPM are obligated to ensure full implementation of the agreed-upon measures, effective from the date stipulated.
A timely transposition was therefore necessary in order to render such measures directly applicable to natural or legal persons at the community level and to ensure legal certainty in the matter.

Mr. President, honourable colleagues, I believe that the approval of the report by my colleague Podima represents a significant step forward for a more balanced, more advanced, and more robust economic and fiscal policy within Europe.

It is now evident to all the urgency of equipping ourselves, as Europe, as a coordination between the twenty-seven countries, with economic and financial instruments capable of governing the economy and not merely being subjected to it.
For this reason, the proposal to tax financial transactions has garnered considerable resonance, extensive discussion, and significant attention.
The fact that the majority of this Parliament voted for this provision is an important and significant development, because for the first time, it did not hesitate and instead took a step forward.
I hope that the Commission and the Council will continue along this path.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I welcome the reports on equality between men and women and on female poverty in Europe, and I am pleased that they have been discussed today, which marks the centenary of International Women's Day.

Despite Directive 2002 concerning equality of treatment between men and women with regard to access to employment, vocational training and professional promotion, and working conditions, further efforts must still be made to achieve genuine implementation.

It is sufficient to consider that, despite the significant increase in female education levels in recent years and the fact that the number of female graduates now exceeds that of male graduates, women remain concentrated in traditionally female sectors, often less well-compensated, and occupy fewer positions of responsibility across all spheres of society.
Lack of access to care services for dependents, such as children, disabled individuals, and the elderly, to appropriate leave arrangements and flexible work options prevents women from working.

I would like to conclude by remembering the women around the world who are fighting for the most basic rights, and I would like our Assembly to express solidarity with Iranian feminist associations that are taking to the streets today, encouraging women to demonstrate without the hijab.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, to all colleagues who have intervened, I finally say that we return to discussing—and I hope we return to acting soon—with specific choices regarding economic policy and common industrial policy.
Thanks to the Lange report, the excellent work done by the colleague, and the communication from President Tajani.

This choice signifies several important things: firstly, the recovery and resurgence of the European economy and the stability of employment lie also, and perhaps above all, in the revival and in support of everything that is already underway.
A manufacturing sector, both within the most advanced and the traditional sectors, because there lies a frontier that is still possible to address and was not so evident until recently.

Secondly, the recovery of industrial sectors in Europe also means that our competitiveness is not determined in the sectors of finance and the service industry, but still here. It is not too late for us to pursue a challenge for Europe to regain competitiveness with the rest of the world in industrial sectors.

The third point is that the new industrial policy focuses on factors rather than sectors, focusing on the factors and tools that can truly promote new enterprises and new resilience and updating capabilities.

Therefore, I believe it is important to underscore, as has been done, these new factors upon which credit decisions must be based. We are requesting new initiatives, in addition to those already announced by the Commissioner concerning credit, raw materials, and energy costs.

innovation, research, the necessity of strengthening in Europe the capacity to transfer technological results of research and innovation into businesses, new products, and new methods and organization of production.

We must leverage a very particular fabric within our Europe, in some countries especially that of SMEs, that of the quality of businesses, the quality of products, in short, the distinctiveness of industry in Europe.
I believe we should rediscover them, let's say, these manufacturing traditions, these manufacturing roots in many countries, to renew and transform them.
Finally, the topic of territory, which is very important.
European policies succeed when they intersect with and find a territory capable of addressing them.
Therefore, thanks to Lange, and we hope for excellent collaboration with the Commission to achieve concrete results in a timely manner.
Many milestones have been achieved, but some battles still remain to be fought.
Today, the urgency concerns women of other cultures living in Europe and worldwide, in contexts where it is difficult for them to claim minimal standards of dignity and humanity.

We cannot celebrate this festivity without placing the question of women in the Arab Muslim world at its center, otherwise we continue to ignore a problem that today concerns them, but soon will become ours as well.
We cannot ignore the emergency figures that grow year after year, even in Europe, in our cities, in the schools where our children grow.
For some time, cases of violence of every kind experienced by Muslim women within their own families have been increasing.

Therefore, I have been asking for this for some time, and I request it again today, that Europe implement policies targeted against the proliferation of Islamic radicalism, against forced marriages, honor killings, female genital mutilation, and domestic violence.
We women, European men, must fight for those women who live in Europe, but not only that, who have no voice and are oppressed by the monster of Islamic intellectualism.

Mr. President, honourable colleagues, I voted in favour of the resolution on Turkey because the constitutional reform, which occurred on 12 September, has been unanimously recognised as a significant step taken by Turkey towards Europe.
Naturally, many steps remain to be taken, and in this sense, I express concern regarding the numerous arrests of journalists.

Notably, Turkey is the seventh trading partner of the European Union, and the European Union is Turkey’s primary trading partner, and that trade relations, correctly interpreted for centuries, have fostered mutual understanding and peaceful coexistence between peoples.

I therefore applaud the notable progress on the front of fostering connections between the European Union and Turkey, particularly those through the motorways of the sea traversing the northern Adriatic and the northern Tyrrhenian Sea.
Upon which now moves a flow exceeding 250 TEUs in both directions, connected to a significant rail and road link from port to inland European destinations.
It has been possible to eliminate a conspicuous flow of trucks crossing land via road, and I hope this continues along that route.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, with today's vote we have given further impetus to the definitive resolution of this problem, but we have not voted for the best possible solution.

Indeed, I wish to recall that the over 300 amendments presented in the report were transformed into 38 compromise amendments, all adopted, which aim to better define the priority sectors of the strategy, that is, the objectives of this strategy.

The Commission, with the permanent task force, must ensure the collection and dissemination of statistical data and good practices, and Member States should appoint a government official, hopefully at a high level, who will serve as a contact point for the implementation of the strategy.
But we could have been even more forceful and less hypocritical if, in the report, we had emphasized the obligations and duties that the Roma community should still respect in host countries.
This is my hope, namely, that solutions are found soon to facilitate a better coexistence of this community in all Member States.
Lampedusa has been inundated by tens of thousands of North Africans whom the island, never, ever, could accommodate.
Italy has been targeted for weeks by hundreds of clandestine boats.
If we do not all react together, if the EU does not react, the wave of people fleeing will continue.
The undocumented migrants who have arrived in recent months must be returned home; there is no alternative.
But the Italian government, beyond some words of solidarity, has been left alone to manage this biblical exodus of unpredictable dimensions—where is Europe?
Until today, Brussels has been repeatedly disappointing, exhibiting a shameful conduct that my fellow citizens can no longer tolerate.
Europe has left Italy alone to face an unprecedented emergency.

Instead, Europe must not only assist Italy in the repatriation of irregular migrants, but must also support the Italian government’s efforts to prevent the continued departure of thousands and thousands of people, particularly from Tunisia.

All of this, however, applies to Libyan refugees, regarding whom Europe must stand alongside Italy in water provision and logistical management operations, but above all, must commit to ensuring that refugees are hosted in all Member States.
The reception of those fleeing war cannot fall solely on Italy.
It is time to stop the talk.
The European Union, if it exists, should make its presence felt.
We cannot tolerate Italy filling up with undocumented migrants, while France repels them with shameful methods.
Irregular migrants must be returned to their countries of origin, while all Member States must commit from now on to accommodating Libyan refugees.
The matter of forecasting adequate financial resources to guarantee the decommissioning of nuclear power plants is an issue already addressed by the European Commission.
European Union legislation on nuclear safety is now highly relevant, in light of recent international events and the subsequent decisions of Union governments regarding it.

The work of Mr. Marinescu, to whom we have expressed our support, addresses the specific cases of certain countries that, at the time of their accession, undertook particular obligations regarding the decommissioning of nuclear facilities and that, precisely for this activity, received special support from the European Union.
Beyond specific cases, from this topic must be established an effective control of verification, as well as examination, of the nuclear power plants located within the territory of the Union.
It appears, indeed, that the number of reactors estimated to be deactivated in the near future within the European Community is considerable.

It will therefore be essential to ensure guarantee mechanisms, even and especially in these cases, for the earmarking of adequate financial resources necessary to address both routine and extraordinary needs.
I would also like to thank the speaker for their presentation.
The report addresses the developments arising from changes in control and communication systems.
Likewise, this highlights a picture of considerable interregional heterogeneity, particularly on the part of the States, in the reporting of irregularities and fraud.

The report repeatedly highlights the peculiarity of low levels of fraud and irregularities reported by several countries concerning agricultural expenditure, structural funds, and pre-accession funds.
It is truly necessary to clarify the statistical data that have been submitted.
The situation is further exacerbated by the well-known failure of recovery efforts.
However, one fact emerges clearly and confirms a long-term trend.

The struggle for legality and transparency in the allocation of European resources, such as the fight against tax avoidance and evasion, cannot yet rely on the full cooperation of the States, the governments together with the European institutions.

In this sense, I believe the proposals for a review of community legislation on public procurement are appropriate, as is the need for what I call a European public registry of beneficiaries of community funds.
I thank the speakers and also Commissioner Barnier for his great availability towards Parliament.
We advocate for a concept of the internal market capable of understanding and satisfying social expectations and the implications that the social dimension entails.
It is not a utopia, it is realism and modernity as well.

It is indeed this vision that makes the market itself stronger, because the purely economic perspective, economicism in essence, the reduction of the market to economicism, has demonstrated how this does not resolve either the problems of growth or those of cohesion.
It is, in essence, a matter of fully realizing, and in the present, the fundamentally European idea of a social market economy.
In today’s texts, this exists.
There is recognition of social enterprises, cooperatives, their role, mutual benefit societies, and foundations—10% of European enterprises and a significant portion of our employment.
they are entities that are veritable companies, a demonstration of economic pluralism and a pluralism of enterprises.

They work with capital but not for capital, and they aim to achieve labor, welfare, quality, and social innovation, demonstrating that these values must and can be part of the internal market in Europe.

Mr. President, the justification offered by Beijing—that the artist Huey Huey was arrested for economic offenses—is unconvincing; nor is it convincing that such zeal is being directed towards a free and dissident artist.
It does not convince, as this arrest falls within the context of hundreds of arrests of opponents and the systematic repression against all dissent.

In the days when the Arab uprisings erupt, our thoughts turn to the image of cruel violence in Tiananmen Square against the young Ginjees who demanded, as they do today with the Gersomino Revolution, freedom and democracy.

China has opened itself to the West on an economic level, without however reconciling production with respect for the environment and worker safety, and is unable to achieve any openness towards democracy and pluralism.

Our actions do not constitute interference in China's internal affairs, as Beijing claims, but rather a call from men and women, from movements, from parties who intend to build a world free from intolerance on every continent.
The government in Beijing should observe what is happening in the world to understand that if it does not change, it will be historical events and Chinese citizens who will change China.
Jobs lost despite several million euros invested in support policies.

This represents a regrettable assessment of the impact on SMEs, of the triumphant Lisbon I project and the copycat Europe 2020 strategy, regarding which it is even being decided to concentrate the resources of the next multiannual financial framework 2014.

I can therefore only reiterate what thousands of European citizens and taxpayers are asking: what is the purpose of Europe if it is unable to resolve the continent’s economic problems and cannot speak with a single voice on foreign policy matters, while wasting money?
I hope that what I have said repeatedly, by Commissioner Tajani, will come to fruition.
I hope that the revision of the SME Code is truly capable of simplifying bureaucracy, ensuring access to and recovery of credit, and facilitating interoperability.
With the directive on late payments, a concrete and genuine milestone has been achieved, but one resulting from political will rather than Europropaganda.

If the costs of yet another financial strategy will only fund more empty words, I urge the European institutions to make amends to the dozens of small entrepreneurs who, in my region of Veneto, have taken their own lives before seeing their small business fail.

Mr. President, while Europe turns a blind eye, the Europol report for 2011 on organized crime asserts that with the accession of Romania and Bulgaria to Schengen, powerful Turkish, Russian, and Albanian criminal organizations will be able to expand their operations throughout Europe.
Again, I quote verbatim: Turkey’s illegal immigration will extend to the coasts of Bulgaria; drug and human trafficking will increase in the hands of Turkish-Albanian organized crime.

Regarding human trafficking once again, the entry into Schengen of Romania and Bulgaria could offer Bulgarian crime and emerging Romani communities new opportunities to increase their already substantial trafficking operations towards the rest of Europe.
Ultimately, increased illegal immigration from Turkey and trafficking in drugs and human beings, less security for European citizens.
Europe wants to do a great favor to organized crime.
The Northern League party is and will always be opposed to this kind of egregious choice.
Whoever votes in favor of this report tomorrow will bear the responsibility for a vote that will open a highway for organized crime, leading directly to the heart of Europe.
Thanks to the Treaty of Amsterdam, environmental policy and sustainability policy gained greater relevance, and the report was received favorably.
The focus has been on the integration between economic and environmental policy, and on incorporating environmental issues into policies and other sectors.

Key sectors include climate change, sustainable transport, nature, biodiversity, health and the environment, as well as the use of natural resources and waste management, and the international dimension of sustainable development.
In June 2006, the European Council, in its conclusions, invited the Union and its Member States to extend national accounts to the fundamental aspects of sustainable development.
National accounts must therefore be supplemented by an integrated economic and environmental accounting system, suitable for providing fully consistent data.
I voted in favor of this regulation proposal because it creates new uses for national accounting data, environmental statistics, and other statistical sectors.

Mr. President, honourable colleagues, my favourable vote on the Garriga report on the forthcoming financial perspectives of the Union stems from the conviction that precisely during a period of greater crisis, evolution is possible.
Regarding the so-called European spirit, it is decisive to insist and prevail on the necessity of providing credible instruments, beginning with an adequate financial endowment for the Union.
Therefore, the request for a 5% increase in the next budget is a fair and necessary request, perhaps not sufficient, but indispensable to provide answers to the major issues before us.
It is necessary to address real problems, such as greater cohesion between regions, enhanced research and innovation capabilities, a stronger ability to generate growth, and to offer employment.

If conditions are adequate, none of these problems will find a sufficient answer, starting with the introduction of this intermediate category into cohesion policy, which makes sense only if it does not cause damage to the other existing categories.
That is why I voted in favor, and I hope that the Commission and the Council will follow the indications of this report.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the new Hungarian Constitution reduces the scope of intervention by oversight bodies such as the Constitutional Court and increases the powers of the executive branch, thereby challenging the ordinary balance of powers.
Social rights are hollowed out; the State provides assistance to the needy only if they accept to perform public utility work.
The right to self-defense is finally enshrined, permitting the possession of firearms at home even without a license.
Abortion rights are prohibited, and strongly discriminatory rules are introduced concerning homosexuals.
All of this is contrary to Directive number 78, which establishes a general framework for combating discrimination.

I therefore ask the Commissioner how she intends to intervene, considering that the fundamental rights of the new Hungarian Constitution are scarcely compatible with those of the European Union and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, we are about to vote on a strategically significant document that provides a robust framework for the negotiations on the financial perspectives post-2013.

starting from the request for coherence between objectives and instruments, between the new role that European institutions are called upon to play after Lisbon and in the face of recession, and the resources that we jointly decide to invest.
This consistency also implies a serious response to the demand for innovation emerging from public opinion, the recipients of EU policies, and European social and productive forces.
We did it for cohesion, a crucial chapter for deciding what we want and what the European Union is to be in the coming years.
It is said that cohesion is today a vital hub of the European project, an important asset for all to safeguard, to protect, to renew.

Particularly critical on this front is the effort made regarding the proposal to introduce an intermediate category of regions, especially because in several cases the years of recession we have experienced have
We have mitigated internal disparities, making even more important an efficient and adequate support for the less developed regions of Europe, combating waste and outlining the development policy.
And yet, I believe that the challenge of intermediate categories with a safeguard clause is a challenge that we must accept to open a new phase in European policy.
of cohesion in Europe and also to substantiate the cohesion policy with that more balanced, more sustainable development that we want to guarantee for Europe in the coming years.
I, too, join in thanking the Honorable Langen and the other colleagues with whom we have worked to finalize this complex report.
I believe that what the Honorable von der Leyen recalled is particularly important.
Langen, when he stated that we want to maintain the scope, the field of application of this regulation, remaining faithful to what was the G20 mandate of Pittsburgh in 2009.
The primary objective is to bring the majority of over-the-counter derivatives onto regulated platforms to avoid continued exposure to a high degree of
When one arrives, as has happened, at exchanging and guaranteeing 400 million dollars without collateral, that is, without adequate reserves, one understands the risks we are running.

Having said that, however, I would also like to mention two problems: the first problem is the relationship with the Council, the second problem is the coherence of the proposed reform of financial markets that we must pursue.

I raise the first issue concerning the Council, and I state it very clearly: the feeling is too often that the Council represents an obstacle to acting swiftly and effectively on the financial markets reform front.
I hope that the new Presidency will take charge of this issue, because even on this occasion we must factor it in.
Taking into account a lengthening of timelines, which is largely attributable to the positions, difficulties, and contrasts that arise during Council proceedings.
It is a problem that concerns the procedure we wish to follow.
The second matter concerns the organic nature and specificity of the measures.
There is not only the measure concerning OTCs, there is also the measure concerning short selling and other matters.

I wish to highlight two points: the specific issue of the raw materials market, a particular market requiring specific anti-speculative interventions, and the problem of local authorities’ exposure to derivatives in European Union countries.
I believe that these are issues on which Parliament should intervene.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the Fukushima incident continues to produce very serious consequences, with the release of seawater and radioactive water 6 times greater than legal limits.
The risk of food products becoming contaminated is high.
Europe has established very strict controls, but this pertains exclusively to fresh produce.
No protective regulations have been issued for processed products, particularly canned fish.
We import 370 tons of canned tuna, and our primary suppliers are the countries of Southeast Asia, which import fish from Japan.
This means that canned fish imported into Europe could contain Japanese fish.
It is fundamental and urgent to provide precise information regarding the place of origin.
Today, consumers know where the box was produced, but not the location where the fish was caught.

The Commission has recently recognised this and intends to fill this gap with the reform of the common fisheries policy, which, however, will not come into effect before two years, just as the Sommer report under discussion in this plenary will not have effect before three years.
We must not create alarmism, but consumers have the right to urgent and transparent information.
The Commission must intervene as soon as possible.
Mr. President Tusk, your address gives us cause for optimism; we hope that the Polish Presidency will be a contribution to the fight against the Europe of egoists.
that it may be a contribution in favor of a Europe that truly thinks of itself as an integrated reality with a common destiny.
But as you rightly pointed out in your presentation, a Presidency has concrete problems to face and resolve.
I wish to indicate to you, in this brief time, two crucial issues regarding the economic and financial crisis.
First, the reform of financial markets.
It is not a technical problem; it is a major democratic issue of our time. The timelines are too long; we must resolve matters such as those pertaining to the reform of short selling and OTC markets.
The second point concerns the taxation of financial transactions; we need to examine this issue closely, and we expect a concrete contribution from the Polish Presidency in this regard.
More than twenty years have passed since the signing of the Schengen Agreements.
No one doubts the advantages of free movement, but it must be recognized that the current arrangement is no longer adequate for present and future needs.

For this reason, Member States and the EU as a whole must commit to reviewing the operational mechanisms of Schengen, ensuring that freedom of movement does not compromise the legitimate security needs of our citizens.

As far as we know to date, the Commission's orientations may also be partly shared, particularly with regard to the introduction of a mechanism that allows States to temporarily provide border controls in case of emergency.
It is necessary, however, to see how this will occur and whether the declarations will be followed by actions and, above all, concrete results.

Certainly, it will also be necessary to undertake a general reform of the European border protection system, particularly its external borders, on which Frontex must as soon as possible become an agency with genuine intervention and support powers for national authorities.
We must protect our external borders if we want to continue with this Schengen.
It is time for courageous choices in this Europe if one does not wish merely to survive.

The crisis has profoundly marked the lives of European citizens and businesses and risks, if we do not react, irreversibly lowering social and cultural quality, well-being, the future of young people, and of Europeans.

Emerging from the crisis means creating remedies for the identified causes, remedies against speculation, to which, if necessary, even the claws must be clipped, by imposing strict regulations on financial markets, remedies that cannot be questioned.

Remedies against recession, remedies against a development model that has placed the individual below profit, remedies against resurgent nationalism which prevents Europe from making the choices that today are its responsibility.

Above all, it is time to define the instruments, the resources, even new ones, to move forward, to ignite the engines of growth, with research, innovation, training, support for productive investments, infrastructure, and employment, because without employment, people are without dignity and without rights.
This report, thanks to Pervaiz Berès and colleagues, indicates a possible strategy for a Europe proud and aware of its role.
To European leadership, if it exists, now it is their responsibility to implement it.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, behind the widespread prosperity of our continent lies a hidden Europe, often invisible, of which we speak as numbers, statistics, and sociology, and not as people in flesh and bone, often women and children or the elderly – that is, the most vulnerable population.
But Europe will not be credible with its citizens if it does not learn to be consistent, and we here want to be consistent in this Parliament, at this stage in Europe’s life.

And so, if we say we are founding the Union on values, on human rights, I do not believe we can interrupt or drastically cut a program for those who are hungry, essentially, for those who do not have the right to food, to access to food.

The fundamental points for an unresolved legal matter are the agricultural fund, the social fund, and, if it is to be social, Commissioner, that it not be at the expense of other social programs, but rather a new, ad hoc fund with appropriate resources.
Let us say we want to guarantee food safety for Europeans, but the primary right to safety is to have it—food that is, in fact, healthy.
Therefore, here is our consistency and our commitment.

Let us therefore posit the existence of a legal solution that ensures continuity and, with the assistance of non-governmental organizations and volunteer work, guarantees the fundamental human right to civic engagement.
Solely to support this argument and highlight two particular aspects—one because it fits into the current debate concerning the relationship—
review of the common fisheries policy and the baseline option, which is linked to the regionalization of a policy that, in recent years, has demonstrated its weakness through centralization.
This phase of regionalization finds a particular application in the Black Sea.

I believe that the elements contained within colleague Iotova’s report describe a particular situation, but one that can also be repeated throughout the rest of Europe. The situation in the Adriatic Sea, within the Mediterranean area, is not dissimilar.

In the Tyrrhenian Sea or the Mediterranean Sea, that is, interactions primarily between European and extra-European fishing, let's say, are interactions often very damaging to European markets and European consumers.
The second matter I would like to briefly highlight is that of a reference to a common coast guard.
There can be no politics without the exercise of control.

The checks today are carried out through disparate forces in Europe, and I believe the time has come to understand how one of the first forces, so to speak, of European order – namely, the coast guards – could have a common management, greater correlation, and why not, a single European body.
With this hope, I fully support the contents of the report by my colleague Iotova.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the disaster that struck the Gulf of Mexico more than a year ago has prompted the European Commission to reflect on the legislation governing the activities of offshore oil platforms.
Even the European Parliament, with this report, wished to express its position on the matter, approving a text that requires adequate technical and financial capabilities.
for industry professionals and aims to establish high safety standards, thereby sanctioning the European Union's leading role in promoting the safety of offshore activities.
The new interventions in the field requested of the Commission must focus on international coordination and a realistic approach that combines all existing excellences.
within the sector at the procedural level and avoids the creation of new bodies or additional bureaucracy, which would risk diverting attention from achieving tangible final objectives.

The report, in concrete terms, beyond increasing the accountability of operating companies, requires improvements to communication and information and knowledge sharing mechanisms and advocates for the strengthening and expansion of the role of the European Maritime Safety Agency’s competencies.
It is for all these reasons that I consider the result achieved to be positive, thanks to the negotiation on this text, to which we have expressed our support.
I thank my colleagues Seeber and Schillaciakis, and I also thank Commissioner Heidegger.

I believe we are gathered here today to discuss and deliberate in order to genuinely achieve a robust European climate policy, capable of safeguarding economic development and the wellbeing of European citizens.
For this reason, Mr. President, international climate policies, as has been recalled thus far, have primarily focused on the reduction of CO2 emissions.
This proposal highlights how we must also address the fight against other anthropogenic emissions that cause the formation of tropospheric ozone, impacting climate change.

Many things have already been recalled that I believe it is right to keep firmly in mind. Today we are able to do so with absolutely reasonable costs, we have the technologies at our disposal, and, however doubtful, it is CO2 emissions that primarily have an impact.

Although it remains questionable whether the other greenhouse gases present in the atmosphere are present in significantly smaller percentages, it remains doubtful that their potential is very high and that we will, therefore, be able to achieve significant results in just a few years, in just a few decades.
They are two important ones.

There are signs, it was also recalled in the United States by the Commissioner; I saw a study published in Nature by the scientific agency of the American Department of Commerce, with which I find it possible.

There are many points of contact with the analysis conducted by our colleagues, and I imagine these will also be factors that will allow Europe to present itself in Durban with an even stronger, more concrete, and more important position.

I conclude simply by recalling, as has already been recalled, that for this extraordinarily difficult and delicate situation we are experiencing – we have been discussing homelessness until just moments ago – there is a sensitivity among European citizens that we must take into account, and therefore considering that the large

Regarding sensitivity, of course, and for employment, we should be able to conduct a communication campaign as well, one that clearly explains to citizens what we concretely intend to do in the direction of development, their well-being, and the protection of jobs.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the single market, the free movement, and the Treaty of Lisbon are all elements that have intervened irrespective of a modification of our legislative approach, the European approach, and the national approach.

If it is necessary to follow up on the commitments that have arisen from these occasions, it is particularly important to initiate a genuine phase of simplification of the legislative system, a phase of simplification that must produce a different dialogue between Europe and individual States.

I would like to suggest a kind of clarity test for our documents when we produce a white paper or a green paper; everything must be more comprehensible, and I would go so far as to say that the true, and perhaps strategic, proposal for our Europe is to genuinely begin.

The solution to this, let's call it virtuous, phase of registration launch is to assign a specific mandate to a European Commissioner tasked specifically with clarifying the legislation and the relationships between the Member States and Europe itself.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, representative of the Council, and Madam Commissioner, first and foremost, I too would like to positively welcome, as other colleagues have done, the anti-corruption package approved by the European Commission last June 6th.
Corruption is a transnational phenomenon, and measures of a European scope are necessary to combat it.
The vast majority of our European citizens, according to Eurobarometer estimates, believe that Europe must do more.
How can one fault them?

In many Member States, the political will to counter corruption has been lacking; it is enough to consider that there are still European countries that have not signed the United Nations Convention against Corruption.

When we consider the devastating impact of corruption on democratic processes, citizens’ rights, and trust in the rule of law, it is clear that the national measures to combat it adopted to date by Member States are insufficient to contain a phenomenon in expansion.

It is the European Union that must provide a unified and robust response, especially now, in the midst of an unprecedented economic crisis, which is weighing on the lives of people, the stability of social security and welfare systems, and the capacity of institutions to guarantee essential services.
Corruption causes the loss of 120 billion euros annually, equivalent to 1% of the European Union’s GDP, and daily diverts resources from the Union and its Member States.
they could be utilized to provide essential services—education, early childhood care, employment, transportation—and to allocate clean resources in support of individuals.

Therefore, it is necessary to demonstrate greater courage and resolve, both in monitoring the implementation of anti-corruption measures and in intensifying and strengthening measures to combat corruption at the Union level.

Specifically, we cannot speak of combating corruption if we are not able to adopt at least minimal norms for the definition of the crime of corruption, of which there is no trace in the recently approved package.
The same applies to the definition of uniform parameters for measuring the extent of the phenomenon in member states, essential for preparing an effective response.
We are, for example, in favor of revitalizing the EU network of contact points against corruption, as proposed by the resolution we will vote on tomorrow.
The crisis is not recent; it has existed for several years.
Has the time perhaps arrived to conduct a critical assessment of the policies followed to date? Has everything always been done well?
We have always conducted appropriate analyses of the situation.
Was the correct approach chosen?
The very European Central Bank, which, as Minister Rostovsky says, saved Europe, has it always acted correctly even when, fearing inflation, it raised interest rates?
President Barroso identifies a problem: the speed of the markets and the slowness of policy, but is this the only problem?

Certainly, if one considers that we are still at the implementation stage of July 21st, this should at least suggest better preparation and organization of the summits and their conclusions, but policy will always be slower than the markets.
Therefore, the point is to look further ahead, to shift the emphasis to the fight against unemployment and towards development.
This is the ground that the European Commission must also address today, in President Barroso's speech, with greater concreteness on the deficit and less on indications of growth and development.

The Commission must move beyond its weakness, stating that the priority is the fight against unemployment and job creation, redistribution of wealth, and a public investment strategy, also changing the rules of the new European Stability Pact.
Mr. President, I believe that the challenge of the coming years is to ensure that Europe, as has been said, maintains its position as leading power.
a world-renowned tourist destination while also being able to enhance—both in terms of environmental protection and competitive capacity—its entire territorial heritage.

It is a challenging and far from guaranteed undertaking, even considering not only the opportunities, but also the aggressiveness of other countries in this sector, from other continents, from China to India to Brazil.
Now, within this framework, the Commissioner Tajani recalled, it becomes fundamental, as also noted in the opinion of the Commission that we approved in the Committee on Regional Development.
to maintain a robust overarching strategy for the entire European Union regarding tourism, alongside a recognition of the role of regions and territories.
In this sense, full involvement from the outset is essential, respecting the principle of subsidiarity of the regions and local authorities.
Furthermore, I believe that the development of integrated tourism networks and projects should be encouraged, starting with the creation of partnerships for the exchange of best practices.
It seems right to me, also, the proposal to identify a Europe brand capable of defining a high quality of the tourist product.
Naturally, it will be up to the Commission to better define the priorities, particularly from a financial perspective, to ensure that this primacy of Europe is maintained in the future.

Madam President, honourable colleagues, the preparation of a common strategic framework for the financing of research and innovation represents one of the greatest opportunities facing European development and the European economy.

It is, in fact, a matter of acting on the lever that can genuinely trigger a moment of growth and also of new, qualified employment, such as that of researchers and young people who are dedicating themselves precisely to new opportunities in innovation, technology, and related professions.
One observation, above all, emerges from this work and that we must increasingly emphasize in Europe a research and innovation that leads to practical application, that leads to

We must foster the birth of new enterprises, which lead to new patents and which do not remain purely basic research, purely knowledge—important, yes, but not sufficient to truly trigger the sprint of development.

The second observation concerns the relationship with local authorities, regions, and territories, which are also an important instrument for territorial planning and for fostering interaction between research, universities, centers of excellence, and businesses.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the European Schools were established with the aim of ensuring access to education in one’s mother tongue for the children of officials of the European institutions required to work and live abroad in a cultural context different from that of their country of origin.
The first European school was established in Luxembourg in 1953, on the initiative of a group of officials.
Over the years, considering the positive aspects of this form of teaching, 14 European Schools have been established within the various Member States.

While acknowledging that the European Schools system represents a necessity rather than a luxury, it is evident that, more than 50 years after the creation of the first European School, the system may exhibit obsolete aspects and must, in some way, be adapted and adjusted to new economic and social needs.

I therefore expressed my favorable vote for the text proposed by colleague Cavada, which seeks to increase the involvement of the European Union in supporting and coordinating the actions of Member States tasked with developing and improving the European Schools system.
It is a company that engages in investment; it is well known that investing in education means investing in the future of our young Europeans.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, in recent decades there has been an exponential increase in the number of natural disasters that have caused the deaths of tens of thousands of people in various parts of the world.
Last year, within the development committee, I followed the work on the report concerning the European Union’s capacity to respond to disasters.
How much more remained to be done to ensure a coordinated response from the European Union in the face of the increasing frequency of earthquakes, floods, or tsunamis?
The European Union’s response to the earthquake in Haiti, for example, clearly demonstrated the complexity of the existing instruments and procedures.

Although Member States and Community institutions have acted promptly in terms of providing humanitarian aid, the management of the crisis has raised a number of issues concerning efficiency, coordination, and transparency.

Precisely for this reason, I expressed a favorable vote for the text presented by my colleague Elisabetta Gardini, which aspires to greater efficiency in all phases of disaster management, and improved coordination.
among the stakeholders involved and a simplification aimed at avoiding unnecessary overlaps and time losses that hinder the provision of rapid and effective assistance.
Yes, it’s merely a good initiative; I believe it will lead to the construction of a European policy concerning tourism.
The European brand is a good idea, but on two issues I want to dwell: there is no seaside or coastal tourism without a policy of coastal planning.

I believe the time has come for Europe, precisely to protect this important sector, to produce an initiative in which the conception of the sea and the conception of the coastline are not limited to a form of urban planning that ends at the high-water mark and does not comprehensively involve the sea.
I believe that an integrated policy is useful in this sense, as it will also be necessary to build everything that underlies the claims of rural tourism.
an excellent source of income for disadvantaged areas, for areas where there is no longer employment, where it is important instead to prevent further depopulation and ensure human settlement.

Well, it's not enough simply to make statements there; rather, one should suggest to Europe and individual states that they intervene on the fiscal levy. Promoting tourism in rural areas might mean paying lower taxes. Perhaps in this way a genuine opportunity can truly be built for the tourism resource and for those who reside there.
I wish to express my congratulations on the work done by the Honorable Fidanza, which logically fits within the framework of actions supporting women.
acquired and promoted at the community level in matters of tourism, after the Treaty of Lisbon assigned the EU new competencies for the sector.
I share and wish to emphasize the assertion of the importance of a Europe as a unified destination for certified and quality tourism.
The same idea, translated into actions at the level of structures, allocation of resources, funding, and coordination of actions among the various levels of government of the Union’s countries.

An approach to be valued and rewarded, given the sector in question, with its implications in terms of percentage of GDP produced, employment, and new opportunities for small and medium-sized enterprises.
For businesses, attention to the protection and enhancement of the environment is capable of developing and, consequently, responding to the primary challenges posed by contemporary times.
For all these reasons, I consider this report positive, an important signal in the direction of promoting a European policy for tourism.
Mr. President, even for recovery, three small considerations require more Europe—also here.
I believe it is inevitable that on certain matters there will be a genuine attitude in which not only is it hoped for, but more Europe is actively built.
More Europe means, for example, beginning to genuinely consider a common highway patrol, identical rules from the perspective of safety protection.
More Europe means having a European education policy, not simply delegating it to individual states, but building, for example, a genuine education policy.
With regard to schools, with regard to young people, and also with regard to categories somewhat more at risk—I mentioned motorcyclists a moment ago, but we can also speak of truck drivers.
For us, more Europe means having common tools within vehicles to improve safety conditions, anti-alcohol and anti-corruption measures.
drowsiness, I believe it is a targeted strategy to be developed with automotive companies and European vehicle production.
I believe that if all of this falls within the framework of a common policy, I truly think that perhaps conditions will improve.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, this report addresses the topic of global food security. Global signifies that this topic is not solely about world hunger in the poorest countries, but that the issue of food supply concerns all communities, including those in the most developed nations.

Outline some lines, like those essential to coherence, between European policies and this objective of global food security, because we are an institution that preaches very well but is often inconsistent in its choices.
I simply want to outline a few other titles—three innovative lines—that I believe we should develop further.
Initially, food supply today is jeopardized by price volatility due to speculation on food commodities, which must be contained if not prevented—derivatives, etc.

Secondly, the issue of land accumulation, which I believe should be the subject of some form of treaty or negotiation, is at risk because of its potential impact on democracy, as well as the survival of many peoples.
Third, the consistency between procurement and energy policies.
We cannot, in order to produce new energy, prevent food from being produced for the peoples of the world.
I voted decisively in favor of this report by Ms. Zimmer, first and foremost for a matter of security, because it is an idea that has not been accepted.
It is of a purely political nature, because I believe it is necessary to bring this significant issue of food security back to the center of the entire European Union's initiative.

It is not only and solely about helping developing countries to address this issue more effectively, but the food crisis, since it is projected that demand for food will increase by over 70% between now and 2050.

Agricultural products represent a significant issue that, if not addressed promptly and decisively, will become one of the primary threats, if not the most important threat, to stability, peace, and even democracy, as has been observed.

For this reason, I believe it is indispensable that the entire European Union, together with its member states, make every necessary effort, beginning with adequate economic investments, as indicated in the report, in this direction, to seriously address this significant issue.
Greetings to the Commission, I must genuinely thank all those who have contributed over these weeks, these months, to the production of this document that we are voting on today in the Assembly.
We worked, I must say very well, and a truly constructive debate developed.
The resolution we are therefore voting on today is the result of a truly collaborative effort and the product of the contribution of all political forces and of the entire Parliament.

I believe a shared and very strong sensitivity has developed regarding this topic, partly because we must remember that we live in an era truly characterized by an exponential increase in catastrophes.
The numbers, if we look at them in their raw state, are very eloquent: the number of disasters worldwide has quintupled, if we consider that in 1975
Seventy-eight catastrophic events had been recorded, whereas we are now experiencing nearly 400 calamitous events per year.

Mr. President, over the past twenty years, unfortunately, there have been 90 or more victims of these disasters, and over 29 million individuals have been affected by them, while the economic losses amount to 211 billion euros.
It is evident that we are confronted with phenomena of such magnitude that they demand a stronger response, a more effective response, and a truly substantial commitment from our side.
We all have in our minds the images of the earthquake in Haiti, the flood in Pakistan, what happened in Japan.
Mr. President, Europe itself experiences sudden floods, fires, and, let us remember, the ash cloud following the eruption of the Icelandic volcano, every year on its own territory.
There is no need to look further to assert how important the work being done here in Parliament is, following two principles.
fundamental, which are our guiding stars, the principle of solidarity, strengthened by the solidarity clause of the Treaty of Lisbon, and the principle of subsidiarity.
We proceed along these lines.

Mr. President, the European Union’s intervention has always been generous and effective in the past, as I believe the work of our Commissioner Georgieva attests, but today we need to take a qualitative leap.
A leap in quality that we are ready to undertake, to move from an ad hoc response to one instead where the reaction
be strengthened through the proactive identification of resources already available in Member States and placed at the disposal of the European Civil Protection Mechanism.
It is also important to emphasize this qualitative leap, and to move from information sharing and emergency response to a role of planning and monitoring.

This is the coordination that we hope for, the fundamental role of services like GMES, and I take this opportunity to also express the concern regarding what is happening with respect to the budget, for these new technologies that are essential.
We have underscored the importance of communication with citizens, because the Japanese experience has also taught us a great deal, and it is never sufficient, never adequate.
And we await from the Commission, to which we request the prompt presentation of the proposal concerning civil protection in legislative form.
Oppressed ethnic minorities, Christians forced to practice their faith in secret, priests barbarically murdered without so much as a gesture from the authorities—this is the Turkey of today.
My party, the Lega Nord, has always opposed Turkey's accession to Europe, because it represents a potential Trojan horse for radical Islamism in our continent.
Today more than ever, we are convinced that the EU must bring an end to the accession negotiations.
The intolerable threats that Turkey has directed towards Europe must have an immediate response.
It is unacceptable for a third country to tell Europe what it must do.
Cyprus is a full member state of the EU and has the indisputable right to assume the rotating presidency.
Europe must send a clear signal and demonstrate its readiness to defend Cyprus by any means against the arrogance and political and military assertiveness of Turkey.
Let us immediately halt negotiations for accession and remain prepared even to suspend commercial relations.
Mr. President, we are living through a decisive juncture for the future of the euro and, with it, of the entire European construction.
Having this awareness would mean moving beyond a myopic logic that subordinates everything to an ideological will for budgetary rigor.
We all want the accounts of the various states to be in order, we all want to reduce debt.
However, it is clear that without an intelligent investment policy capable of revitalizing the economy, there will be no possibility of growth.
