The only clear outcome in this scenario is that the heaviest prices, as always, will be paid by the weakest.
For this reason, together with the group of socialists and democrats, we voted against this report.
Indeed, one proceeds in a single direction, that of rigor without growth, a direction that has proven to be incorrect thus far.
The work that colleague Ferrera did on this report is greatly appreciated.
Indeed, of the six legislative proposals dedicated to economic governance, only on this one did I and my group express a positive vote.

We did so because a clause protecting social rights has been included, among other things, stemming from collective bargaining, and furthermore, there is a strengthening of Parliament’s role in the adoption of delegated acts.

Therefore, while not being able to alter the overall balance of the package of six proposals, this report undoubtedly represents a step forward in ensuring, among other things, a surveillance system that takes into account fundamental rights.

Therefore, in this context, I maintain that a vision, in our judgment, based solely on a policy of austerity, does not produce positive results; this report undoubtedly constitutes a positive note in contradiction.

Mr. President, honourable colleagues, Finland and the Netherlands raised the matter in Council for a very simple reason: Bulgaria and Romania are currently unable to guarantee effective border controls, and this is due to three acts of unjust corruption involving the political class and organized crime.
It is not the populist parties and movements that think this way, but Europol, in its 2010 report on organized crime.
There is no populist propaganda, but a serious security issue.

Should Bulgaria enter the Schengen Area at this time, law enforcement and security agencies anticipate that Bulgarian borders, particularly those along the coast, would become an easy target for Turkish and Eastern European criminal organizations, and Bulgaria and Romania would become the focal point for human trafficking and drug smuggling.

It is natural that some Member States have many reservations regarding the actual ability of Bulgaria and Romania to guarantee effective border controls against organized crime and corruption, and it is therefore absolutely natural that they opposed their entry into Schengen.
Allowing it now means paving the way for transnational crime and creating a breach in European borders, precisely where there is intense migratory pressure from Turkey.
The reasons for opposition are numerous, and Europe cannot ignore them.
I therefore request information regarding the intentions of the Commission and the Council with respect to this delicate matter, which, in my opinion, has been handled thus far with
a failure and without considering the dangers that the entry of Bulgaria and Romania would entail, according to the competent bodies in matters of security and international crime.

In my view, the Commission and the Council should postpone the accession of these two countries to Schengen and give their approval only when there is reasonable certainty that the accession of Bulgaria and Romania will not have repercussions for the security of European citizens.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the crisis in Europe is entwining the problems of public finances and private capital with those of the productivity of our businesses, and the specter of recession looms.
Therefore, if the priority of SMEs is crucial, I ask the Commission to absolutely, together with Parliament, ensure that the principles, our good principles, are put into practice.
In practice, it is that the legislative initiatives of the SBA, the Small Business Act, become a concrete practice for Member States, with a high level of effectiveness and quality.

Consider, Commissioner, what it would be if all Member States advanced the application of the directive against late payments? What great advantage it would be for SMEs? Then SME evidence is important, but we are still at a methodological level.

Certainly, it is right to verify whether when we legislate, we do so truly in the interest and tailored to the needs of small and medium-sized enterprises, but we request that this process proceed with great consistency and tenacity, let us say, in depth, in creating this framework of opportunities that you have outlined.
We appreciate what is being done by the Commission as well, and we are ready with the budget and with other possibilities at our disposal to support it.
I shall say only one word about credit.
Let us have a clear discussion with the banks, I say this to you, Commissioner, because it is necessary to support small and medium-sized enterprises.
Mr. President, honourable colleagues, I have expressed my favourable vote for the text of the honourable Ms. Wallis.
Without prejudicing the usual avenues of access to justice, I am convinced that alternative dispute resolution (ADR) represents a rapid and cost-effective alternative to legal proceedings.
Beyond being an effective tool for small and medium-sized enterprises, ADR can also see significant development online for the resolution of minor disputes.

Through a joint activity with Member States, it is therefore necessary to foster the creation of a harmonized legal framework that, by strengthening citizens’ trust in the internal market, can contribute to stimulating the European economy.

The report concerning the provisions for sectors placed on the market under flexible arrangements, to which we expressed our favorable vote, was inspired by a measured and realistic approach that materialized in a report.

on the one hand, in avoiding the imposition of unrealistic and impossible-to-satisfy requirements, and on the other, in establishing a so-called flexibility regime structured around the provision of time periods and corresponding quantitative work limits.

permitted emissions, foresees the issuance onto the market of a predetermined annual quota of tractors meeting specific characteristics, thereby allowing the adjustment to established standards to be diluted over time without causing disruption to the productive and industrial sectors involved.

Mr. Tartarella, the work performed has been significant, and he has demonstrated a careful balancing act between the needs dictated by the major challenges facing the European Union at this time and those of environmental protection and the current economic crisis.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the current global economic crisis, even more severe than that of 1929, has caused unsustainable imbalances in international economies in recent years.
Trade imbalances between countries, financial markets lacking common regulations, and the instability of banking systems are all potential threats to financial and economic stability.
This resolution, to which I express my support, urgently underscores the necessity of a complete reform, new rules, and global economic coordination.

The economy requires a system of global governance, open markets, high economic and social standards, more responsible monetary policy, and stricter supervisory policies; decision-making bodies and international economic organizations must be the principal actors at the center of this new approach.

Europe, specifically, needs a transparent framework to reduce instabilities exacerbated by globalization and to guarantee far-reaching reforms aimed at promoting growth and reducing the debt of individual states.
This is the commitment and this resolution underscores for all countries.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I have cast my vote in favor of the report by my colleague Mattera, which analyzes the situation of single mothers, who today represent, as has already been stated, more than 5 percent of the European Union’s population.

The European Union therefore has a moral obligation to protect them, and the text approved today supports those policies that can represent concrete assistance for these women, such as tax relief for women.
healthcare, flexible work opportunities that allow for work-life balance, priority access to affordable pricing, and special unemployment benefits.
Only through the adoption of these measures can we respond to the needs of a group that is increasingly significant in all advanced and industrialized countries.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the budget sets out a few clear and important objectives within the framework of the EU 2020 strategy; for this, my thanks to the rapporteurs.
It is essential to focus on investments and not solely on prudent balance sheet management.
The alternative would be to passively witness the speculative philosophy that characterizes our time.
We can no longer afford to pursue individual interests, but must finally represent a single, cohesive entity ready for engagement.

I commend the commitments undertaken regarding pilot projects and preparatory actions in rubric 2, as well as ensuring that funding for the integrated maritime policy does not compromise other initiatives and programs within the fisheries sector.

This will allow us to implement new policies towards a better management of marine resources through comprehensive research and data exchange regarding fish stocks, imposing new projects that in the Adriatic area can be utilized as best practices in other marine areas.

I conclude with a brief note for future discussions concerning the ECB, and particularly regarding the fisheries fund. I hope that a greater effort will be made on controlling fishing activities – the core of the fight against illegal fishing, but also the foundation for the reconstruction of fish stocks.
that fish be considered a common resource.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the economic, financial, and social crisis we are experiencing has clearly highlighted several weaknesses of the European economic and social model.

I believe that one of the most alarming and representative pieces of data concerning the current situation is the near 6 million jobs lost over the last three years, figures that, as this situation persists, are destined to increase if a prompt and effective response is not forthcoming.

The colleague Bastos’s text emphasizes that, to make concrete progress, better synergy is needed between education, training, and the labor market, combined with policies aimed at ensuring a greater responsiveness between the demands and supply of that market.
For these reasons, Mr. President, I have expressed my favorable vote.
I have cast a favorable vote for what was presented by the Honorable Angelilli because I am addressing an issue that deeply concerns me, both as a mother and as a grandmother.
Protecting children from sexual exploitation, abuse, and the abhorrent world of pedopornography means defending our children, our grandchildren, and consequently, defending the most vulnerable.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, we all know how important the role played by the International Criminal Court is, which deals with prosecuting the perpetrators of war crimes, crimes against humanity, and genocide.
Unfortunately, in recent times the Court has been increasingly subjected to unjust political attacks.
His arrest warrants have often been disregarded, and consequently, the current balance does not reflect the efforts and commitment invested.

I have therefore cast my vote in favor of the text approved today because it is the duty of the European Union to undertake all political, diplomatic, and logistical actions to support the Court and ensure its independence and proper and effective functioning.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the phosphates present in laundry detergents for domestic use end up in European waterways, in rivers, streams, and lakes.

Phosphorus determines an acceleration of the reproduction of various forms of life; consequently, algae and other rapidly developing plant species proliferate excessively when there is an increase in phosphorus presence in an aquatic environment.
This excessive algal growth depletes oxygen for other living organisms, can also produce toxins destroying fish and plant species, thereby reducing the quality of the water itself.

I have therefore expressed my favorable vote for the text voted on today, because to purify Europe's water resources it is desirable to reduce the amount of phosphorus that flows into the waters of our continent.

Mr. President, honourable colleagues, the European Union has produced a vast quantity of laws, regulations to construct European law, and has created the European area, known as the Stockholm Programme.
There is a misalignment between this corpus, this legislative monument, and its usage by citizens, which is numerically and proportionally very low.
On the other hand, national judges and national lawyers of the individual States have grown within the law of their own country and possess primarily training in this area.
This is the meaning, while we think that the true European judge is the national judge who changes his mindset and imbues himself with knowledge of European law.

Therefore, before discussing training, it is necessary to address broad communication with citizens and legal professionals, so that they may become advocates for this significant development and foster the desire to utilize the benefits of this right.

But then, above all, it is a movement that must be generated from within continuing professional development; one cannot teach as if to schoolchildren in the judicial training of adults who are professionally very accomplished.

It is necessary to stimulate curiosity when dealing with one’s own cases, to connect with other colleagues, and to find solutions, given that common law and civil law converge today, and are no longer as distant as they once were within the legal culture.

This is the key point in our proposals, and I am pleased that the European Commission has been convinced by these aspects. In our view, we are requesting a reversal of trend, prioritizing legal studies over judicial training.

There exists an example in the Netherlands called Eurinfra, which is very interesting; it is a network of officers in each Court who disseminate this knowledge and encourage the magistrates in this regard.
Here, the core of our project lies in this; we hope it will receive full support from the Commission.

Mr. President, esteemed colleagues, I would first like to express my sincere appreciation for the work that colleague Giegold has done on this own-initiative report, and I also recall that he and others share with me an active presence in this Parliament’s intergroup on social economy.

My political group, as you know, believes that the social model is one of the founding characteristics of the European integration project, therefore not one of many policies, but a policy that defines our project itself.

And in these times, with attacks also linked to necessities, cuts in public spending, etcetera, we still defend this conviction, this priority, knowing that it can be an updated, modified model, but we also believe it must be maintained, defended, and reaffirmed precisely as a priority.

Therefore, I believe that, within this same perspective, we must also value economic entities that engage in business and produce goods and services, such as cooperatives, and which have a very particular role in what is known as the European social economy.

they reiterate that production can be achieved, good things can be done, efficiency can be realized, even if profit is not the objective, but rather, for example, that of employment, welfare, the enhancement of labor, and contribution to the life of the local community.

Therefore, it is important to conclude, Mr. President, that Europe make available the instruments useful for an active policy and draft a good statute—not the one currently unusable—but a good statute for cooperatives can be a way to help this sector, so important.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the role of the cooperative movement has always been important in building a more balanced and more equitable economic dimension.

It is a moment of profound change, and at this time when we are navigating one of the most severe economic and social crises since the post-war period, the role of cooperative societies becomes crucial.

there has been a robust development of the cooperative dimension within the economy, resulting in a subsequent increase in employment, more qualified work, and a more balanced redistribution of the wealth produced.
It is therefore positive that the European Union has adopted a statute for cooperative societies, but now more than ever it is necessary that there be a genuine simplification of the rules.
We need to reinvigorate the creation of a common European framework in the field of cooperation, and this must occur by providing assistance rather than creating bureaucratic obstacles.
Therefore, I voted in favor of this resolution and I hope that the Commission and the Council will actively work to resolve the issues cited.

The salvation of Europe's millions of unemployed does not depend on the faltering assistance provided by the European Regional Development Fund. Data collected reveal that the majority of the Fund’s beneficiaries are unable to find new employment, while the more fortunate are reintegrated into the labor market with fixed-term contracts, even lasting only six months.
In many cases, it is the unemployed who forgo this fund because they doubt its usefulness.
The FEG is not a solution nor a stopgap to the disastrous consequences of a European trade policy managed dangerously and with excessive lightness by the Commission.

To combat the scourge of now structural unemployment, Europe must curb its excessive openness to the markets of developing countries, whose actual competition constitutes the primary cause of the failures of our businesses.
Until Europe ceases to promote economic self-harm, defending a short-sighted position regarding global trade flows, our businesses will continue to fail.
The fund can only provide temporary support, but it is not through training courses that our unemployed will find serenity and security.

Mr. President, I voted in favor of this proposal, as it aims to update the 2004 regulations in order to incorporate the amendments to national legislation of the Member States concerning social security and to keep pace with the changes in social reality that affect the coordination of those security systems.

This proposal also incorporates proposals from the administrative committee for the coordination of security systems, the purpose of which is to improve, modernize, and bring into compliance with what is stipulated in Article 72, paragraph f, of the previous regulation.

The modifications contained in this proposal indeed aim to guarantee legal certainty for the interested parties and furthermore seek to ensure appropriate coordination at the level of the European Union of national social security systems.

It also reflects the regulatory changes that have occurred at the national level, and its approval was necessary because it takes into account recent developments in cross-border mobility that impact the coordination of social security systems.

We are utopians.

No, because a European internal market requires tariffs to be analogous between domestic and non-domestic users; there is no longer a difference if we are discussing a single market, and especially because there is no technical justification for the increase in costs.
I remember when, in 2007, we began discussing voice roaming, the first roaming of the third [generation] we were using.
There was a certain incredulity and also a certain difficulty, not on the part of the Commission—I must give credit to my predecessor, Commissioner Reding.

The difficulties were widespread, stemming from those who argued that a genuine market position does not anticipate regulation of tariffs, that these are political prices, belonging to an outdated conception of the left, and so on and so forth. Conversely, there were those who claimed it wouldn’t work and would thus hinder the market, but ultimately, we did it.
The realization that these technical justifications for the increase in costs were absent led to a step forward.
Therefore, the world progresses, things become ever more, let us say, possible, and for this reason I believe that an even more audacious outcome is possible.
Final observation: since no further observations are possible today, we had a delegation of Tunisian citizens, I don't know if they are still present.
Perhaps, among the many benefits, this extra-EU expansion helps us understand that the possibility of use, without the genuine fear of costs, also aids democracy.
In Europe, there are over 120 million broadband users, with at least 70 million citizens utilizing their mobile devices to connect to the internet, work, study, or simply access information.
Thanks to this regulation, the European Union has finally decided to intervene in favor of all these consumers, reducing the cost of international telephone calls, data, and SMS traffic.
A positive decision, as the price reduction program will lead to an average tariff decrease of 35% over the next three years.

However, this is not sufficient in a challenging moment such as the present one, both economically and in terms of employment; communication, new technologies, and innovation are a primary asset that Europe must defend with greater resolve.
Every European citizen must be able to circulate freely among the Member States, benefiting from the telephone tariff established by their national operator.

Enough fraud and exorbitant bills for those who travel within the EU. If we truly want to provide a concrete response to citizens, let us therefore create a sort of telecommunications Schengen area, which no longer imposes different rates on citizens depending on the countries in which they operate.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I was part of that delegation from the European Parliament that visited Sicily last November.
Our head of delegation, Cecilia Wistrom, wrote a letter to the Italian minister, the interior minister and chancellor, and received a response that provided us with reasonably clear answers.

I want to remember, above all, the fact that after that visit to Italy, the government changed, and the approach to the situation also changed, but the situation itself changed in the countries from which the migratory flow primarily originated.
However, this should not deter us from the necessity of a careful analysis of what has happened and also of the current situation.
The most relevant fact that remains current today is the status of Lampedusa as an unsafe port, the closure of the first aid and reception center in Contrada Imbriagola following the fire of

The first was the 2011 disaster, which damaged it but only partially, that is, a dormitory destroyed, one damaged out of seven buildings in the facility, and then the de facto termination of the project.

Now, let us consider that in the Mediterranean, the only insecure port was Tripoli during the time of Gaddafi, and I do not find this analogy particularly flattering, considering that migratory flows, even if considerably reduced in number, even for seasonal reasons, are consistently increasing.

They certainly haven't stopped, and it is important that a first aid and reception activity functions – and functions in Lampedusa, which is the first port of call for those arriving from the other shore after journeys that were neither easy nor without risk – as is well known by the Somali shipwreck survivors who have arrived in Lampedusa.

In April of this year, after witnessing the deaths of 10 people aboard the vessel they were traveling on, or the 20 who were transferred from Linosa due to a lack of space in other reception centers, or the 18 who still reside in the stadium locker rooms on Linosa.

The tourist residence of Cala Creta, where they are currently housed, is certainly neither a CIE nor a CAR, and above all, both the healthcare system and the possibility of requesting asylum have been dismantled in Lampedusa.
Everything is entrusted to the good will and the kind hearts of the Carabinieri on duty or the citizens and volunteers of Lampedusa.
Another consideration to be made is the function the center itself had assumed in the recent past.

To have allowed, in defiance of every legal and ethical norm, thousands upon thousands of people to accumulate in a location that, by capacity and by the function it was designed for, could accommodate only a few hundred.

Allowing a territory of only a few square kilometers, already challenging due to its location and logistical difficulties, to be compelled to accommodate a number of people exceeding its own inhabitants must now entail further action.
We must reflect on the responsibilities for a situation of extreme tension.
It is not possible that it is in arrest in the fire itself.
I believe that colleague Rinaldi’s excellent presentation was successful in the chamber.
I wholeheartedly share the favorable assessment of the report.
Nevertheless, I would like to raise a small point: our Europe, with respect to this new world seeking democracy and different economic conditions, is an Europe divided by the Mediterranean.

It is precisely a particular attention to the Mediterranean that I would like the Commission to devote, both with regard to environmental aspects and with regard to the economic transactions that take place in the Mediterranean.
Nedran is a fishing ground.
We are constructing a new fisheries policy in Europe, which will establish very stringent rules on the part of Europe.
On the other hand, there are no rules whatsoever.
And so why not utilize fisheries agreements, providing support to these countries so that they implement the same rules that apply in Europe?

This would be beneficial for European fishing, beneficial for the sea, for environmental conservation, to ensure this fragmentation diminishes and becomes increasingly a homogenous place upon which to build the future of Europe and this new world.

With the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, the European Parliament has become a fully-fledged institutional body in the field of security policies and consequently has the right to actively and decisively participate in the priorities of the internal security strategy and the Union’s security model.

Colleague Borsellino’s report identifies the five key sectors for which concrete actions have been proposed and advocates for greater judicial and police cooperation among Member States to address organized crime and terrorism.
I believe it is of particular importance to strongly consider the development of prevention policies, which are fundamental tools for guaranteeing a European space of freedom, security, and justice.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, with the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, the foundations have been laid for the development of criminal law integrated into Community law.

Asserting the importance of mutual recognition, the harmonization of protective regulations, and the principle of the presumption of innocence, it is important to emphasize how the law must be of utmost clarity and easily comprehensible, so as to make clear to all which action constitutes or does not constitute a crime.
This is particularly true for directives that must correspond to national law.
Any lapse in charity could, in part, give rise to divergent interpretations of the law.

I therefore believe that only close collaboration between European institutions on the principles and methods to be followed can guarantee a coherent and high-quality European strategy in the field of criminal law.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the European Union safeguards the general interests of consumers against unfair business practices, misleading advertising, and abusive contractual clauses, but there is no solution.
It is doubtful that consumers who are most vulnerable due to age, physical or mental health problems, or simply a lack of adequate information should not be protected with greater care.
I therefore expressed my favorable vote for the text proposed by Colleague Perez, because I agree that the creation of a strategy for consumer law
the so-called most vulnerable contributes not only to their social inclusion, but also to ensuring a single market that is safer, fairer, and more competitive.
Colleague Perez’s report, to which we expressed our favorable opinion, concerns the need to consider the drafting of a report for the future.

A strategy is directed towards the protection of the most vulnerable consumers' rights, in anticipation of the strategy that the European Commission and Member States will be called upon to develop for this purpose.
Consumer vulnerability stems from causes of diverse natures and may potentially affect everyone.

For this reason, it is necessary to provide protection for this category alongside that of the general consumer and to develop, for this purpose, a targeted strategy that, when considering the composite nature of the problem, avoids

On the one hand, the formulation of static and rigid definitions incapable of considering all facets of the issue and the various possible forms of vulnerability, and on the other, averting the creation of new forms of discrimination.
It is therefore necessary to arrive at the definition of specific and targeted protective measures.

Mr. President, honourable colleagues, the management of red tuna fishing has a long, rather complex history since the nineties and is, to this day, probably the most strictly regulated by the European Union.
Despite the substantial investments in control measures, which have led to greater observance of regulations, concerns regarding the problem of overfishing still persist.

I have therefore expressed my support for the Romeva i Rueda report, which proposes a reduction in the permissible catch rate, increased control, and a strengthening of measures for capacity reduction.
Mr. President, honourable colleagues, relations between the European Union and China clearly demonstrate imbalances at the commercial level.
It is therefore incumbent upon European institutions to strive to assist European businesses in emerging from the crisis and to ensure fairer access to international markets.
I therefore expressed my support for this report, sharing, in particular among the issues highlighted by the rapporteur, the application of the principle of reciprocity to relations.
relations between the European Union and China to enable fair competition on international markets and the demand for greater protection of intellectual property rights.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the road ahead is still long, but today’s could be an important step finally toward the introduction and application of a financial transaction tax.
I understand Commissioner Schmetta's prudence, caution, and the need for gradual implementation, as well as the technical issues rightly discussed by Minister Vestager.

But precisely for this reason, I hope that Parliament will express a clear political will, with a broad majority, to provide impetus and drive to the initiatives necessary to address the issues that remain open, especially at the Council level.
We all want to carefully evaluate the impact of this tax, but it is not fair to stir up unfounded fears, which can also lead to contradictory and counterproductive choices.
I am referring, for example, to the logic of the proposed exemptions.
If one is attentive to mitigating the impact of the tax, then it is important to have the broadest possible tax base, with a low rate, and not to seek to extend exemptions indefinitely.

To those concerned about the effects on small investors, I recall the progressive nature of the tax, whereby those who conduct more transactions and make larger investments are affected to a greater extent.
of transactions and it is clear that the competent authorities will in any case need to monitor to ensure that the costs, should they arise, are not passed on to customers and end users.
Therefore, I hope that Parliament will pass a vote with a large majority in favor of this tax.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, since 1990, through the instrument of macrofinancial assistance, the European Union grants economic aid to countries experiencing short-term balance of payments difficulties in the form of grants, loans, or a combination of both.
The rather lengthy timelines, compounded by the difficulties evidenced in the decision-making criteria used thus far, have necessitated the formulation of certain regulatory amendments.

I therefore welcome the proposal introduced in the new regulation, which aims to make the evaluation criteria faster and more effective and to establish clearer rules and conditions for the provision of macro-financial assistance.
Mr. President, esteemed colleagues, there are approximately 100 million European citizens engaged in various voluntary activities.

From major sporting events to cultural occasions, the role played by volunteers is fundamental, and the work of those who come to provide assistance and solidarity in the event of serious natural or environmental disasters should not be overlooked.
Volunteering represents one of the broadest expressions of active citizenship and a crucial activity for the development of democratic values and equality within the European Union.
For this reason, I advocate for the development of high-quality volunteering, both national and cross-border, and the elimination of currently existing obstacles.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, from the communications sector to finance, transportation, and energy, from culture to healthcare, the role played by technology is increasingly relevant.
The increasingly frequent use of the Internet and digital media makes cybersecurity one of the priorities on the European agenda.

Information and communication technologies can indeed foster economic and social development only if existing regulations guarantee the security of users regarding data privacy and intellectual property rights.

For this reason, only full international cooperation involving Member States, institutions, and industry can give rise to a robust system capable of introducing effective measures to ensure cybersecurity.
Madam President, thanks to the Commissioner, important and shareable points have been made, which are very significant.
I find it genuinely, as he said, unsettling that we have each lived in our own country with the numbers and figures that we heard earlier from colleague Oconio.
2020. But it is equally evident that this scandal has truly highlighted the need for a careful evaluation of the current European legislation on medical devices.

Unfortunately, this fraud has highlighted the shortcomings we have discussed thus far in this chamber, which has so aptly represented the Commissioner, and for which I would not want to dwell on this aspect within the limited time I have available.
I believe it is beneficial to deploy everything necessary so that we may offer the best possible service to our citizens.
But I believe that this scandal, which has taught us so much, could also be a catalyst for taking another step forward, and I refer to what the colleague before me mentioned.

The communication provided to patients is truly inadequate; only the positive aspects are consistently emphasized. The idea of eternal youth or promised beauty is presented, whereas there are no prostheses entirely devoid of risks.

I believe that this awareness, especially when discussing purely cosmetic surgery, must genuinely be communicated to people, to young women, because we know that there are very young individuals approaching this type of procedure.
Therefore, I see that you are absent in conviction, and so I implore you, let's truly work; the deadlines are tight, we should have completed it already yesterday.

Mr. President, esteemed colleagues, the Council’s regulations regarding the multi-year herring stock plan were adopted prior to the treaty’s entry into force and therefore an alignment has become necessary.

This regulation, the first in the fisheries sector to be aligned with the treaty, is therefore of considerable importance, as the solution adopted in this case could impact the decision-making procedure applicable to other multiannual plans.
For this reason, I cast my vote in favor.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, from Seveso to Bhopal to Toulouse, numerous environmental disasters have struck Europe in recent years, jeopardizing the health of European citizens.

The colleague Ader’s text concerns the revision of the SES II Directive, which aims to contain the effects of incidents involving substantial quantities of hazardous and highly polluting substances released into the environment.

The revised regulations, which will come into effect starting in June 2015, aim to protect the environment and, above all, to limit tragic consequences for the health of citizens; therefore, I have expressed my favorable vote.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I too thank Stevenson for the excellent work and the direction he has given to this report, which substantially addresses the two main issues.

This is not merely a herring management plan; it is fundamentally about ensuring a future for fishermen in some respects and implementing marine planning to ensure this, over a multi-year period, has its protections.
But the key point of this report remains the issue of delegated acts.

I believe that the Council must accept the framework established by the Treaty of Lisbon, and I also think that the time has come for the Parliament, in some way, to have a voice perhaps more authoritative than that of the European Parliament.
whether it’s a debate within the fisheries committee or a debate on a report concerning cod, to have the courage to take a very clear and firm position regarding the issue of delegated acts.
We assert the right that there be, on these matters, a genuine ordinary procedure.

So perfectly that the issue also involves, in addition to numerous other sectors of fishing—sectors which, incidentally, will worsen compared to the ongoing reform—but concerns matters pertaining to agriculture and other themes.
The essential element is the respect for the will of Parliament.
In the preparation of this report, no consideration was given whatsoever to the directly affected parties, the haulage companies.
In Italy, 91% of freight transport occurs by road.
Their rights will be disregarded if this report is approved in its current form.
In many committees of this Parliament, we work daily to reduce the financial and administrative burden on our businesses, but reports like these undermine those efforts.
We must exert every effort, for companies themselves will be stifled by new bureaucratic burdens, devastating economic losses, and new forms of unfair competition.
It would have taken little to achieve a balanced account that did not forget the right of our companies to survive in a very difficult economic period, but such a dialogue proved impossible.

Conversely, the report deliberately disregarded even previous legislative acts of the European Union, such as the 2002 Working Time Directive, and even overlooked documents from the European Commission that recognized the hazardous nature of practices like retrofitting, which, however, is reintroduced in this report.
Colleagues, the document we will vote on tomorrow will ask you to disregard the positive achievements made in recent years, and European businesses will once again bear the costs.

Just to say, Mr. President, that ACTA was a very serious political mistake—let’s set aside the legal aspects—it triggered a reaction in the world of immense proportions, and this alone is enough to say that it was a political error.
But why the Bense?
Why did it create the suspicion that access to the web was genuinely closing, which is a significant modern revolution?
And why this?
Why did he make the mistake of conflating counterfeiting and piracy, which are two distinctly different phenomena?
The way to combat counterfeiting has nothing to do with copyright.
And then there is another error, which has excluded Parliament from an important activity it has been undertaking for some time, namely, the creation of a new copyright, a new author's right.

The old copyright law that existed before the web. The point now is that we must work on copyright and set aside ACTA, which is an obstacle, and reject and exclude it, because it is an impediment to our work.
Fortunately, the Commission, after months and years of hesitation, has brought two important measures—orphan works and the forthcoming one on copyright management societies—before Parliament.
Alright, let's work on this by reflecting with our minds and not just our emotions, but without hesitation.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, simply to add my voice to the praise this report has received in the Chamber regarding the need to strengthen the European Union’s ability to address future challenges.
to be a place where it is possible to invest, produce, and manufacture within the framework of our conception of an inclusive economy, socially and environmentally sustainable.

Therefore, I believe that some of the guidelines here within this provision are very useful, others could be added, and I believe it’s important to gather these guidelines and work increasingly so that attractiveness remains paramount.
as a consequence of territorial policies, territorial marketing, and openness initiatives—wherein the territory itself proposes a productive and industrial vocation.

that originates from the territory should be respectful of all environmental compatibilities and, at the same time, European policies that move in this direction, a voice from the territory and Europe that is attractive for investments and growth.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, when discussing sensitive topics such as the authorization of products and substances for use in organic productions, we are discussing the protection of the health of European citizens.

It is indeed important to respond to consumer expectations regarding the quality of organic products circulating in European markets and to ensure adequate application of Community legislation by authorities, bodies, and operators involved.
Therefore, I express my favorable vote for the colleague’s text.
Pia has offered the initial comments on the Council; now, the phase of reductive reading has begun, which is incorrect, as significant progress has been made.
Consider, for example, the breaking of destructive links between banks and public debt, and the, albeit weak, plan for employment and work.

It appears that the spirit of revival and a renewed path toward political unity is returning to European institutions, after so much sluggishness and torpor, and a will to achieve real progress for greater integration.
We have observed significant unity between Parliament and the Commission on this matter.

I do not speak of victors and vanquished, but it is undeniable that there has been a new institutional and political vitality compared to the past diarchy, which was the negation, the very antithesis of community spirit.
There has been a multi-country initiative and activism, not already to create new exclusive axes, but to build a common and respectful consensus among all member states.
This is the path to the political goal of unity, without which every banking, fiscal, and monetary union will be entirely inadequate.
June 6th, with the Council’s decision to return to Member States the possibility of reinstating border controls, a new Europe was born, an Europe courageous in fulfilling the desire of all.
and greater security of its citizens, is finally inspired by a more mature interpretation of the concept of solidarity, redirected towards the defense of the rights of its peoples first and foremost.

To President Schulz, even though he is not present, I say that this historic decision does not represent an inter-institutional incident, but respect for the will of the citizens, and not for that Eurocracy that for years has pretended not to understand what is truly happening outside the glass palace.
No imaginary influx of undocumented migrants, Mr. President Schulz, but an increase in illegal immigrants, measured by Frontex, of 35% in 2011.

I regret only that the scenes of political sectarianism enacted in this Chamber and during the previous plenary session have stolen time from a more useful and constructive activity: questioning why, in defending the interests of our citizens, it was not we, but the Member States, who were involved.

If Parliament does not find its own spirit and the courage to go against the prevailing orthodoxy, the sterile platitudes upon which it has drifted for too long, it will continue to be a follower rather than a leader in the construction of the European project.
I wish to draw the attention of this Assembly to the fact that yesterday was a
We have officially announced that the Higgs boson has been measured and concretely identified.
The particle that gives mass to all the others and their existence—this occurred on European soil.
Science gives life to our land, civilization, and well-being, and for a moment we can aspire to return to being a world science capital.
Utopia is the characteristic of the human being who invents an utopia and wants to realize it, and it is for science and for this wonderful ambition of humankind that today a person
A blind person who lacks eyes can see with their hands or read a book with their ears, and a young South African man who lacks legs can run in the Olympics in a speed competition.
Indeed, Europe must be the home of science; this momentous event that will open new frontiers to knowledge must be fully supported by Europe.
Mr. President, honourable colleagues, all too often within the European Union, victims of crime fail to report incidents due to fear or a lack of trust in institutions.
The text voted on today aims to strengthen the rights of victims of crime and to guarantee them the same level of protection, assistance, and access to justice under safe conditions.
all countries of the Union, paying particular attention to those victims who are at a high risk of suffering further prejudice or intimidation during the criminal proceedings.

Of particular importance is therefore the recognition of victim status not only for individuals who have suffered harm as a result of a crime, but also for family members and the deceased resulting from the crime.
On September 11th, the Catalan people peacefully demonstrated in Barcelona.
One million people have requested the independence of Catalonia from Spain.
On October 15th of last year, the British Prime Minister Cameron signed the agreement to permit the referendum for Scotland’s independence from London.
In Veneto, my region, in recent weeks thousands of people have signed to initiate a referendum for independence from Veneto and from Italy.
Yesterday, in Veneto, in Lombardia, and in all the regions of Northern Italy, hundreds and thousands of people signed petitions requesting greater autonomy from Rome.
But even in Flanders, in the Basque Country, citizens are loudly demanding autonomy and independence from the nation-states.
What does President Schulz say?
It calls for a courageous commitment to clearly say no to all separatist tendencies.
His deputy, Vidal Quadra, even worse, has invoked the use of force against Catalan citizens.
Their statements constitute a most serious act, contrary to the principles of that democracy which we preach here and which we must defend.
I tell them that the peoples will write the future of the new Europe, and not the bureaucrats of Brussels.
The path is already laid out.
The austerity policy adopted to emerge from the economic crisis has not yielded the hoped-for results.
as has been pointed out by the report from colleague La Via, only by investing more selectively and supporting the ideal of a European budget sometimes too constrained.
To support growth and employment, it will be possible to rebalance the economies of the Member States, thereby improving the situation of European citizens.
For this reason, I have therefore expressed my favorable vote.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the social and economic context in which the multiannual financial framework for 2014 is being discussed is rather problematic.

With Member States committed to implementing fiscal adjustments to their respective national budgets to consolidate public finances, the European Union is, in some cases, perceived as an entity that exacerbates the financial burden on taxpayers.

Therefore, to genuinely emerge from the crisis and guarantee a better future for young Europeans, it will be of fundamental importance to support greater and more tangible investments in the sectors of training and development.
This is the programmatic document of an institution from which one can understand what it is, what it does, and above all, what it intends to do in the future.

We are facing a crucial choice between a survival budget, a budget of dragging along, perhaps a little less for everyone, or a budget of courage, of selective choices, of investments in employment, in innovation, and in young people—that is, for the future of the European Union and its vocation for development.

Everyone should understand that, as colleague Calfin clearly stated among others, Europe can do today what States can no longer do for the economy, for regional development, for the territories where social cohesion is either affirmed or undermines the lives of the citizens we have discussed.
Major European decisions risk being stifled today by accounting disputes within the Council, but not only between beneficiary, payer, and paying countries.

We say it is a false problem, because it is easy to demonstrate with figures, with numbers, not with words, based on what has happened in the past, that contributor countries, sometimes more than others, benefit from the convergence of economies and from growth.
The Council is currently working to assign figures to the various items.

The war of positions has begun: declarations, stances taken by certain states that view the budget in the wake of any expenditure item, which can be cut without remorse, indeed, perhaps even useful to bolster an anti-European sentiment easily provoked in times of economic crisis.
It is a mistaken position that does not aid the integration we are seeking to achieve in other fields.
Dear colleagues, our Europe is still incomplete and mutilated, as we have said so many times.
We adopted a stability pact, which was also intended to be a development pact, but we have become so stabilized that we are in recession.
Here, let us at least seize the opportunity of this budget, this multi-year framework, to make choices in the right direction.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the lack of information and awareness regarding one’s rights, compounded by economic obstacles, is not a solution.

Language barriers and the non-recognition of diplomas and qualifications are the most common issues encountered by citizens of the Union when residing, studying, or working in another country of the European Union.
Unfortunately, there remains a lack of visibility regarding the concept of Union citizenship and its tangible benefits.
For this reason, I have expressed my support for 2013 as the European Year of Citizens.

The primary objective is, in fact, to strengthen awareness of the rights associated with Union citizenship and to assist citizens in fully exercising their right to free movement and residence within the territories of the Member States.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the proliferation of innovative financial instruments poses numerous challenges in terms of regulation, governance, and control of their effectiveness.
It is, therefore, necessary to find a proper balance between the objectives of transparency and control, as well as a sufficient level of effectiveness and speed of implementation.

The introduction of such instruments at the European level remains of considerable importance, as it represents a means by which the European Union, particularly during times of crisis, can stimulate investment in the economy.
real, in accordance with its own objectives, in a context where the continued decrease in responses allocated to the Community budget contrasts with the constant growth of its political ambitions.
Regulation Brussels I has undoubtedly represented one of the most effective acts of European regulation concerning safety and workplace safety.
of Union legislation, as it established the foundations of a European judicial space promoted and underpinned by legal certainty among European citizens.
The dissemination of this regulation addresses fundamental themes for the development of European justice, including the extension of rules regarding
on the jurisdiction of disputes involving parties domiciled in third countries and agreements regarding the selection of the competent forum.

I am convinced that the approval of the new regulation may guarantee more robust consumer protection and greater legal certainty within the internal market, and for this reason I have expressed my favorable vote.

Mr. President, Commissioner, today Europe is required to undertake a new task of coordinating industrial policies, and even the staunchest proponents of autonomy and private initiative now call for the exercise of this role.
Without greater Europeanization of national strategies, even in terms of employment protection, the current crisis cannot be overcome, and there will be no recovery.
The automotive crisis is not merely overcapacity; it is a dramatic loss of employment.
But the crisis now appears structural and concerns the very destiny of the car, as a product, in its current form.
We want to keep the automotive industry in Europe and we want to avoid dispersing existing skills and know-how, professional expertise.
Therefore, we request that a large-scale project of renovation and revitalization be initiated, and that it be undertaken expeditiously, as costs are proportional to time.
Restructuring cannot be merely the result of fragmented national decisions or individual enterprises.
It is necessary to at least attempt to coordinate and guide this painful process at the community level, bringing the interested parties to the table through social dialogue.
producers, trade unions, and the governments of individual countries, offering the support of research, innovation, human capital development, reskilling, and the necessary funding.
I know it will be an arduous task, because the national interests of individual enterprises are not aligned.

But since the competitive interplay currently taking place within the European Union is often ambiguous and occasionally risks being unfair, I believe it is ultimately in the interest of all countries to have an effective communal impetus and guidance to jointly confront the increasingly aggressive global market.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the energy crisis has exacted and continues to exact a very high price from all employment, impacting thousands of precarious, permanent, and temporary workers—a significant number within this sector.
The largest steel groups are increasingly oriented towards the Far East or the American continent, posing a significant question regarding the direction of our development model.
I believe that Europe must rediscover the idea that a manufacturing system like ours needs solid basic productions capable of supplying the European internal market.
We must therefore defend this sector, the role of a stable steel industry, and we will support it, Commissioner, if we want to halt industrial decline.

I believe we need to move somewhat beyond a dualism that isn’t fully articulated here this evening, but which is often heard in discussions concerning this sector—a dualism between environmental advocates and workers—which is incorrect because it fails to reveal a perspective for the future.
An industry that views steelmaking as an integral component requires advanced production systems, concrete and balanced solutions that safeguard diverse interests and needs.

Therefore, a robust and forward-looking approach is needed, even at the European level, that prioritizes sustainability—a principle on which, in my view, we must not regress, considering it a genuine value-added element with which we intend to compete globally, supporting investments.

We have heard from various sources about new technologies, new processes, and the requalification of plants for a European economy that effectively utilizes resources, including energy resources, indeed starting with energy resources, and also concerning the research of new and different materials.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, as we have recalled in this Chamber, next December the United Nations agency dedicated to telecommunications and information technologies will convene in Dubai for the World Telecommunications Conference.
The subject is the renegotiation of international telecommunications regulations.

We must not forget; I am pleased with the words of Commissioner Tajani, the work that has been done to date, which cannot be called into question, nor can we allow the authority of the European Union to be bypassed.

a supranational structure like the ITU, of which we know hundreds of States from around the world are members, many of whom are known for problems related to democracy, transparency, and freedom of expression.
Therefore, it is not incorrect to believe that the pillars of the Internet—freedom, participation, openness, innovation—are at risk.

Therefore, I believe it is necessary to protect the role of the Internet and the role that, above all, the Internet can have in reinvigorating economic growth, but also to guarantee opportunities for all.
I therefore hope that the Commission will work towards the goal of a united Europe in Dubai, speaking with one voice.

Numerous controversial proposals have been presented at the negotiating table of the World Conference on International Telecommunications, particularly those that envision changes to Internet governance, which challenge network neutrality, with negative implications for consumers.
Thus, the freedom of the Internet is at risk, or, more precisely, the freedom of expression and the protection of data.
What some states have proposed would in fact allow a government to meddle not only in the communications of its own citizens, but even in the data transiting across its networks.
The step from here to the limitation of freedom of expression and to censorship is extremely short, and therefore I believe it contradicts the fundamental principles of the European Union.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I have expressed my support for the text proposed by the colleague and, in particular, I concur with the rapporteur in emphasizing the fundamental role played by national judges in the application of law within the Union.

I therefore consider it necessary to fully support the efforts of the European Union aimed at improving and coordinating training in judicial matters for judicial and administrative authorities, and for legal professionals.
Furthermore, all sectoral initiatives should be intensified to fully realize the concept of a Union founded on the rule of law.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, in recent years, the extraction of hydrocarbons, so-called unconventional, including shale gas and shale oil, has determined a transformation unlike any seen before in global energy markets.
Europe, in order to address this situation and become less dependent on hydrocarbon imports, will therefore have to rely on its own potential reserves of gas and shale.
In this regard, some Member States have already authorized shale gas exploration and are preparing for the extraction phase, should a discovery permit it.

In such a context, it becomes necessary to monitor regulations concerning shale gas extraction within the borders of the European Union, to ensure that the effects of its cessation are not diminished.
The extractions, undoubtedly valid from an economic standpoint, do not create environmental problems concerning the potential release of harmful substances into groundwater or the atmosphere.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I believe that today’s occasion should be used to speak objectively about Kazakhstan and the important agreement that the country is negotiating with the European Union.
Kazakhstan is a crucial country with regard to the stability and strategic future of Central Asia and is undeniably an important economic and commercial component of the European Union.
This is a country that has already initiated a process of economic reform and a democratic process, but which still needs to commit significant effort to bring these processes to full fruition.

It is, however, a country that, with this objective, continues to demonstrate its readiness for new and more robust reforms, and I believe that this is the task of the European Union to accompany them.

Therefore, I am certain that the signing of this strengthened agreement will allow for advancements, because its approval will reinforce an already solid and productive relationship and ensure consistent assistance from the European Union.

I remain convinced, and I believe this should have been highlighted even more in the report we will vote on tomorrow, that progress toward democracy and human rights must be accompanied by a renewed, reciprocal commitment—open and constructive.

Our objective should not be to adopt a negative stance towards these and other countries in the face of the failure to promptly implement changes; our objective should be to support the efforts of these countries to achieve the goal of respecting human rights principles as well.

Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, honorable colleagues, I would like to thank the rapporteurs for the reports we will vote on tomorrow, just a small passage concerning the spin-off, and I concur with what I heard this evening as a unanimous voice from all my colleagues.
But I wanted to dwell on the Ferrera paper, which I greet and congratulate.

I wished to say that with the past common policy on fishing, one has only contributed to increasing the disconnect between the institutions that regulate fishing and its true actors, namely, the fishermen.

Unfortunately, until now in Europe, the lack of a proper definition of artisanal fishing has disadvantaged those who have always understood fishing as an activity linked to the traditions of their place, their seas, and their cuisine.

Thus grew the conviction that the line followed by the European Commission was to standardize all fishing in Europe under large-scale industrial fishing, following only market logics and not heeding the reasons of thousands of fishermen for a couple of

For decades, they have operated according to rules pertaining to ecosystem conservation, with which I can only agree, but which have never preserved the working activities of the microeconomy of artisanal fishing.
This initiative report sends a strong signal to the Commission and may translate into practical actions benefiting the micro-fishing economy.
The report, indeed, highlights a series of advantages deriving from the allocation of a minimum sum to small-scale fisheries within the European Fund.

It will be necessary to incentivize projects with integrated solutions that benefit the coastal community as a whole, and furthermore, Commissioner, encouragement of young people's access to employment opportunities will be indispensable.

We have discussed this matter on several occasions in committee, because otherwise not only will fishing likely die out due to the degradation of the seas and fish stocks, but it will probably die out because young people no longer approach this sector.
This report provides an opportunity to incorporate training and incentive moments for young people seeking to enter the sector.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, like many colleagues, today I ask the Council that made this proposal, but what do you want to do, gentlemen of Europe?
Do you want to minimize it, freeze it in the future?
But it is that very Europe that subsequently seeks to revitalize itself with the Van Rompuy document on integration.
But with what consistency, I ask you, does Varro Poirier conduct these two dossiers?

And what consistency can citizens find between the decisions of July, employment and growth, the resounding calls for hope and the future within the European Union that we also hear from the Council, and this violent fall, then, in the name of realism, into a perspective of minimal survival?
How will it be possible, with these figures and these cuts, to translate the much-touted major reforms of cohesion and the CAP into concrete actions and active policies?

Here, these are sincere questions; we would like a clear, honest answer, because there are here the signs of an institutional schizophrenia that Parliament no longer accepts, that citizens no longer accept.
Parliament desires consistency, desires credibility.

The first criticism is that on the budgetary level, we simply aren't there; forget growth and investment, we’re at the 2008 budget. It must be acknowledged, however, that concerning rubric 1a, Van Rompuy's proposal overturns the scandalous Cypriot proposal.
It is true, here the role of the budget is recognized as an irreplaceable catalyst for growth in certain sectors, in addition to national budgets.

But both growth and innovation, let it be clear, must not come at the expense of other sectors that are also part of growth and jobs, such as cohesion policy and, dear colleagues, also agricultural policy, which has increased employment and is increasingly oriented towards innovation and the protection of the territory.

Our territory, growth and jobs, culture, education, transnational networks, the Structural Funds and Cohesion Fund, and also solidarity and international development, human rights worldwide, and our contribution to the Millennium Goals.

Before us, however, lies the usual spectacle of the Council: no vision, no guidance, a babel of conflicting and competing national interests, an inextricable animosity of vetoes, expectations, and general discontent.
And Europe, unfortunately, is the great absentee.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, spin-off fishing is an environmentally unacceptable practice, as it threatens the sustainability of certain shark species, which, from that perspective, are endangered.
social and economic, as it involves the waste of a foodstuff with commercial value, as well as from an ethical standpoint, since it demonstrates a complete lack of respect for animal life.

Although this practice has been prohibited since 2003 in European waters and for the European fleet, the Commission has decided to present a proposal aimed at eliminating even the exemption from the prohibition on removing shark fins onboard fishing vessels of the Union.

This proposal, in addition to further safeguarding sharks and the protection they require, will thus allow the European Union to actively contribute to the global effort underway to eradicate the cruel practice of shark finning in other parts of the world.
